to your skin. It will help you feel better and make everything heal
faster. If you are getting a cold, try making a tea from the
beautiful flowers. It will help with swollen, sore throats and stuffy
noses. PROJECT IDEA: When a bunch of your calendula flowers have
bloomed, pluck them off the stocks and set them out on a cookie sheet
to wilt for a day or two. Then, put all the flowers in a canning jar
and cover them with oil. Make sure you shake it around to get out the
air bubbles! Leave your jar in a warm, dry place for two weeks and
shake it every few days. After you've waited, strain out the oil.
Make sure to squish the flowers through something like cheesecloth to
get all the medicine out. Label your jar, and presto! You've made
your very own healing oil! It is good for cuts, scrapes, burns, dry
skin, bug bites, rashes, and so much more!”
Not
only will this book be fun and interactive, but it will be beautiful!
The flower images will be block prints and the book hand-bound and
hardback. The spine will be exposed, which means that when you open the book, it's
flexible spine allows it to lay flat to make reading and coloring
easier. Seed packets and instructions will accompany each plant
picture in a fun and handy pocket page. In it's entirety, I envision
creating a lovely, functional piece of art that is accessible and
enjoyable for kids as well as parents.
Now
you know what I'm doing, but how will I use your dollars? I will put them entirely toward supplies! I sat down and priced out
everything I need to print this book in a run of 35 copies and it
will be between $250 and $300, not including shipping. This includes everything like glue,
paper, bookboard for the covers, waxed linen for binding, ink, blocks
to carve the images on, seed packets, etc. Now, Indigogo allows a minimum goal of
$500 for their campaigns, so any money I receive past my personal
$300 goal will either be used to print a second run of this exact
book if there is demand for it, or go directly into the other publications projects I will be
putting the profits from this book toward. It's important to me that
you understand that this book and any money you may donate is not
just a one-time deal for me. It's like a seed! It is the beginning of
something much bigger that I have been dreaming up for the last two
years, something I am about to invest three years of my life going to
school to study. It is how I eventually would like to support myself, my
daughter, and indirectly, my community.  


Will
you help me plant the seeds and watch them grow?

What
can you expect when you donate? First of all, you can expect to hear
that I have printed and bound a book by (ideally) July 1st.
Second, if you make a donation using one of Indigogo's “Perks”
options, I am using this as a venue to pre-order books and prints.
For a $20 donation, I will send you an original block print of one of
the images from the book. For a $35 donation, you have pre-ordered a
book and you will be the first to receive it once they are completed.
For a $50 donation, it's the book and a print for you. If you would
like to donate more and want a book and/or print, I am happy to set
them aside for you. If you would like to donate less, that's great
too. Perhaps you will want to purchase a book once they are
completed, or perhaps you are just happy to help. No matter which way
you go, I'm so grateful!
Can't
donate? I totally get it! If you don't have the dollars but are
interested and want to help, you can do that by sharing this campaign
with folks and check out my Etsy and Facebook pages!I'm so excited!

story:
When we first saw the dusty warehouse in Portland's West Bayside we knew something great would happen there. A month and a half later we have erected walls, built a stage, set up lighting, installed soundproofing, cleaned, swept, cleaned… We have repurposed the vast majority of our construction materials including several wooden beams from a 200 year-old barn. 

The necessity for a Portland collective such as New System is apparent. By providing a venue that requires nothing but the enthusiasm and donations of the attendees we become an accessible venue for patrons of the arts.

Now we need your help in moving this collective forward. Your contributions will allow us to complete our plans for a designated woodshop, a soundproofed recording/practice studio, refinished and polished interior walls, and to cover the expenses of maintaining the space (rent, utilities, maintenance).

The creative minds of Portland are with us and we want to continue to provide a home for under-represented artists. We have hosted our first two shows and couldn't be more excited by the enthusiasm of the stellar turnout and galactic sounds of the participating musicians. Donations are what will make this collective move ahead and provide multiple creative events a week ranging from poetry readings to punk rock, photography to stand-up comedy. We strive for events that marry multiple mediums of artistic expression, for instance; music in collaboration with visual art.

We have a variety of perks for your generous contributions. Affiliated bands have provided digital downloads for your perusal and download. One of our talented partners will offer one-on-one lessons on saxophone, piano, or drums. Affiliated artists have donated artwork; which you will receive with a certain donation. For your premier benefactors we will offer New System’s unique and eclectic facilities for your use in hosting a private party. We will provide booking assistance in finding the right entertainment for your event. All contributors will hold a place in our 'Hall of Leaners'. Those who involve themselves with New System earn an honorary place among the folks we lovingly refer to as, 'Leaners'. 

The survival of this collective is only possible with volunteerism and donations. We are aware of the hurdles on the road ahead, but we take confidence in the passion of our supporters and in the artists we support in turn. By achieving our fundraising goal we will be well on our way to utilizing the space in such a way that it becomes self-sufficient. We will rent stage or studio time by the day for those who temporarily require the space. The space will be well equipped for private parties for which we will assist in booking music and other entertainment while the woodshop will be producing a variety of furniture to be sold to primarily benefit New System.

Your contribution means the world to us and takes us a step closer to assuring the survival of this collective: the hearts and creativity that call New System home.

story:
In brief

Berlin based Galerie Pavlova is calling on your support as it enters its second year of operation with big plans for 2015.
Following an intense first year we are planning to maintain this momentum as we further establish Galerie Pavlova as a premier platform for showcasing contemporary photography from Australia & New Zealand within Europe.
After having presented a number of established and emerging photographic artists to a warm reception at our home on Linienstraße, we are now working towards participating in our first Art Fair dedicated to promoting photography.
Galerie Pavlova is completely self funded and like many artists we represent, we depend on alternative sources of income (teaching, consulting, lighting design) in order to keep the gallery open. 
It is for this worthy cause that we're reaching out to the greater artistic and photographic community for your support.

The story so far

It has been almost a year since we presented Between Worlds from Polixeni Papapetrou and realised our goal of establishing Berlin's first and only gallery dedicated to presenting contemporary photography from Australia & New Zealand. 

Between Worlds - Polixeni Papapetrou

The first vernissage and grand opening of Galerie Pavlova was complemented with German wine from a small independent winery, and mini-pavlova from which our gallery for Australian & New Zealand contemporary photography takes its name.

 

In the last 12 months we've presented four unique and well received photography exhibitions; hosted an artist talk; conducted a number of interviews; participated in local art tours; collaborated with a number of our neighbourhood galleries; developed our own signature gin; and started a collection of photography books. 

Frühlings Salon (Spring Salon)

Following our first exhibition and coinciding with the 10th annual Berlin Gallery Weekend, the Frühlings Salon (Spring Salon) was a presentation of 20 different photographic artists from Australia & New Zealand. 

    

One of the goals of Galerie Pavlova was to challenge any preconceived notions people may have had about photography from Australia and New Zealand.  

The Spring Salon featured a diverse mix of conceptual, landscape, portrait and classical work of the following Australian & New Zealand photographic artists:

  • Donna Bailey
  • Jessie Boylan
  • David Collins
  • Michael Corridore
  • Sharon Danzig
  • Tara Gilbee
  • Nadine Hattom
  • Derek Henderson
  • Alexander James
  • Ingvar Kenne
  • Bronek Kozka
  • Becky Nunes
  • Polixeni Papapetrou
  • Isobel Parker Philip
  • Clare Rae
  • Jacob Raupach
  • Talia Smith
  • Anita Totha
  • Lesley Turnbull
  • Kylie Ruszczynski

Typologien

Typologien was our first group exhibition featuring the work of three Australian, one New Zealand and one German visual artist who are all living and working in Berlin. 

By an interesting coincidence, each of the artists in this show had produced a series which was reminiscent of the German photographic tradition established by August Sander and Bernd & Hilla Becher - typologies.

The five photographers featured in this exhibition were:

  • Boris Eldagsen - Germany
  • Conor Clarke - New Zealand
  • Henry Trumble - Australia
  • Nadine Hattom - Australia
  • Zoe Spawton - Australia

 

The opening reception of Typologien was well received, bringing together five different photographers who could share their experiences of each project. The many visitors also gained valuable insight into these works, discovering the amount of time and research dedicated to producing a photographic typology. 


Transcendental: New Australian Abstract Photography

The final exhibition for 2014 was a group exhibition of new Australian abstract photography, under the title Transcendental. This exhibition presented work which challenges both the limits and expectations of the photographic medium.

  

Transcendental presented the works of the following five Australian visual artists, working with photography:

  • Jacqueline Ball
  • Michael Corridore
  • Tara Gilbee
  • Isobel Parker Philip
  • Kate Robertson

----------------------------------------

Other milestones throughout the year

We wanted Galerie Pavlova to go beyond the traditional exhibition space; it should also be a window to Australia & New Zealand, a place for cultural exchange where visitors can experience photography in a way they would not otherwise be able to.

Coinciding with the Typologien group exhibition of Berlin based artists we hosted out first artist talk with Zoe Spawton, Conor Clarke and Nadine Hattom. 

  

We also took the opportunity to visit each of the Berlin based artists at their studios or apartments, giving additional insight into their respective projects and photographic work, through a series of portraits and interviews. 

As the gallery is not only a place for showcasing contemporary photography, but also a platform for collaboration and cultural exchange, we have taken the opportunity to work together with some of our favourite neighbourhood galleries.

   

Together with the team at Michael Reid Berlin, we designed and produced a small map of the Berlin-Mitte gallery district. 
For the Spring and Autumn gallery season we have had the pleasure of bringing together the following galleries and institutes:
  • ifa-Galerie (Institut für Auslandsbeziehungen)
  • Rasche Ripken
  • Martin Mertens
  • Galerie Hiltawsky
  • Loris
  • Robert Morat
  • Galerie für Moderne Fotografie
  • pavlov's dog
  • Michael Reid Berlin
  • janinebeangallery
  • Podbielski Contemporary
  • Pinter & Milch

 

Another popular highlight was our collaboration with local gin distiller Alchemist who helped us develop our signature Galerie Pavlova Gin, infused with Australian botanicals and available exclusively through the gallery. 

We have also started a small collection of Australian & New Zealand related photographic publications available for purchase. 

About the founder

  

Michael Dooney is a Gallery Director, Photographer, Lighting Designer, Consultant & Educator. Living and working in Berlin, Michael holds an MA in Architectural Lighting Design and is a design member of the Illuminating Engineering Society IES and Berufsverband Bildender Künstler Berlins E.V. (Association of Visual Artists Berlin). Michael’s photography and light installation’s have been exhibited in Australia and Germany. He also regularly lectures with the NODE Center for Curatorial Studies.

  • Interview in Bpigs - Berlin Independents Guide
  • Commissioned Judge for Reminders Project Grant
  • Lecturer with Node Center for Curatorial Studies

--------------------

Why do we need your support?

Last year we turned to INDIEGOGO to help launch Galerie Pavlova and we'd once again like to call on the community to help us enter our second chapter. 
This year we are planning to take part in the inaugural Photo London Art Fair for contemporary photography. This will be a huge undertaking for the gallery and a very important step in establishing our presence in the European art community. 

Participating in an Art Fair is an enormous investment for a gallery, the upfront costs can be very intimidating and there is no guarantee that work will be sold. In addition to these fees, work will need to be transported from Berlin to London, as well as travel and accommodation costs for our staff to attend. 

Though on a positive note, participation in  Photo London will allow the artists presented by the gallery to reach a very exclusive audience of photography collectors and aficionados, who are devoted to supporting photographic art. 
It is for this reason that we once again call on the wider community to help us achieve this goal. 

What we can do for you

Since opening the gallery we have received many requests from artists, both in person and via email, to review and exhibit their work. In the beginning this was easy for us to manage, however due to the number of requests we now regularly receive, it is unfortunately no longer possible nor feasible for us to accommodate and respond to these enquiries.

   

Therefore, in return for supporting our campaign, we would like to provide this unique opportunity for artists working within the medium of photography to have their work viewed by the gallery.

How does this work?

Similar to when you submit your work to a competition or to a portfolio review, we would ask that you prepare a selection of your images that you would like to receive feedback for, in addition to:
  • Link to your website or online portfolio
  • Artists Statement
  • Biography
  • Any specific questions that you'd like addressed
Once the above information has been received, we will conduct a preliminary review of the submission, compiling a list of notes and comments about your work.
Following this we will arrange an appointment for a 20 minute Skype consultation in which you will have a chance to speak about your work and receive valuable feedback from the gallery.
To complete this process will be sending a follow up email with useful links and resources for promoting and improving your work.

Why is this useful?

Over the years, we as artists have all paid to submit our work to portfolio reviews and photography competitions, only to receive a rejection letter in return, with no explanation as to why the work was not accepted. This can be both frustrating and disheartening, not to mention a time consuming and costly exercise. 
To coincide with our campaign, we would like to offer an alternative to this one way submission process; providing valuable feedback to your work and a positive investment in your own artistic practice.
  • Expert Advice: One-On-One Portfolio Reviews
  • 7 Myths About Portfolio Reviews Debunked
  • Attending My First Portfolio Review After Thirty Years as a Photographer
  • Portfolio Review Dos and Don'ts

Personal Coaching and Portfolio Development (Berlin Only)

The portfolio reviews outlined above are one of the main focuses, simply because they are not restricted to location. However if you are located in Berlin, or have the possibility of spending a period of time in the city then you have the opportunity to take part in an individual coaching session. 
With the personal coaching sessions we can look much deeper at your work and assist you in refining your vision and developing your artistic voice. This will include 20 hours of contact time, spread over the course of one month, in which we can assist you to develop a body of work. 
Please enquire for details and how we can tailor-make a programme for your personal photographic artistic development. 

ADDITIONAL REWARDS FOR SUPPORTING

Photo shoot with Visual Artist Boris Eldagsen

We first showed the work of Berlin based visual artist Boris Eldagsen in our Typologien group show mid 2014. We interviewed him about his included series Safety by Numbers and we spoke about his latest project THE POEMS which is currently on show at Projektraum | PhotoWerkBerlin. 
THE POEMS is a unique photographic experiment in portraiture, where Boris produces an image that is the product of his subconscious mind interacting with the subconscious of his subject. 
I am trying to get a map of psychological or unconscious, subconscious archetypes that I react to. I have done it for the last two years using Tumblr, intuitively liking images that I respond to, without thinking about it. Every 6 weeks I look at all of my likes and try to analyse, why did I like it? What is the structure and how many similar images did I select before? So I came up with about 30 categories or more and this is a kind of map of the images that I respond to on an intuitive level. When I work with models I send them this list and ask them to select 5 categories that are the most interesting to them. Out of those 5 categories they get 5 images each that I collected from tumblr. Then they need to pick the images that they respond to the most. This creates a cross over between their subconscious and mine and it’s from these images that I start creating the staged photography from. 
For a limited time, it is possible to experience this process first hand, as Boris has kindly donated 3 photo shoots to the campaign. This includes a made-to-measure photo shoot utilising the process outlined above, and a print from the collaboration.

Limited edition prints exclusive to the campaign

Also featured as part of Typologien group exhibition of Berlin based photographers, Conor Clarke and Henry Trumble have each donated exclusive limited edition prints of their work to support our campaign. 
This is a unique opportunity to purchase a work from these emerging photographers who are gaining attention both in Europe and in their respective home countries of New Zealand and Australia. Either piece would make a worthy contribution to an existing collection or make a great initial purchase for anyone looking at collecting photography. 

Melbourne based artist, Kate Robertson, who we will be representing this year at Photo London has also donated the above piece to the campaign. 

Circle Work 12 (2013) is a photogram, that being an image produced through the photographic process without the use of a camera, produced by hand by the artist in the darkroom. This is a unique silver gelatin print, faithful to the chemistry and history of photography, however leaving no negative or reproduction available. 


First featured in our Frühlings Salon and later in group exhibition Transcendental, Michael Corridore has generously donated the above piece in support of our plans.

Untitled 13 (2006) is from the widely celebrated Angry Black Snake, published in Hijacked 2 Australia | Germany, among other significant publications both online and off, this successful body of work also won the 2008 Aperture Portfolio Prize. 

Edition 4 of 13 is produced exclusively at 31,53 x 21cm for the Indiegogo Campaign. 


Photographic Prints from Gallery Director

Director of Galerie Pavlova, Michael Dooney is also offering the above images in an open edition of prints, especially to benefit the crowdfunding campaign. Under the working title of Moving Still Life they are an attempt at showing an old subject in a new and interesting way. 

Screen Printed Galerie Pavlova Eco Tote Bag

   

Fickle Sense, Berlin based screen printer and eco-fashion-blogger, has donated her time and skills to produce these amazing custom Galerie Pavlova screen printed tote bags.
All bags are ethically sourced, ecologically produced and hand printed in her studio in Berlin. Available in three colours: mandarin-red, marine-blue and classic black.

--------------------

The impact of your contribution

By supporting our campaign, you'll be helping secure the future of Galerie Pavlova, and give our represented artists (and future artists) the exposure they deserve.
The first year of running the gallery has been met with many challenges and as a young business it will be a long while before it is financially self sufficient. 
Like many of the artists that we support, it is the money that we earn through other means (teaching, consulting, lighting design) that we then invest in the gallery: enabling us to provide a much loved platform for Australian & New Zealand contemporary photography in Europe. 

Other ways you can help

We understand if you're not able to contribute financially, and appreciate all contributions no matter how small they may be. Every little bit counts and will go towards the upkeep of the gallery and our plans for 2015. 

Even if you are not able to contribute, we would really appreciate you spreading the news of Galerie Pavlova and our fund raising campaign. You can also keep up to date on our website and the usual social media avenues:

Official Website: http://www.galeriepavlova.com
Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/galeriepavlova
Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/galeriepavlova

Portfolio Review Dos and Don'ts


Personal Coaching and Portfolio Development (Berlin Only)The portfolio reviews outlined above are one of the main focuses, simply because they are not restricted to location. However if you are located in Berlin, or have the possibility of spending a period of time in the city then you have the opportunity to take part in an individual coaching session. With the personal coaching sessions we can look much deeper at your work and assist you in refining your vision and developing your artistic voice. This will include 20 hours of contact time, spread over the course of one month, in which we can assist you to develop a body of work. Please enquire for details and how we can tailor-make a programme for your personal photographic artistic development. ADDITIONAL REWARDS FOR SUPPORTING


Photo shoot with Visual Artist Boris EldagsenWe first showed the work of Berlin based visual artist Boris Eldagsen in our Typologien group show mid 2014. We interviewed him about his included series Safety by Numbers and we spoke about his latest project THE POEMS which is currently on show at Projektraum | PhotoWerkBerlin. THE POEMS is a unique photographic experiment in portraiture, where Boris produces an image that is the product of his subconscious mind interacting with the subconscious of his subject. I am trying to get a map of psychological or unconscious, subconscious archetypes that I react to. I have done it for the last two years using Tumblr, intuitively liking images that I respond to, without thinking about it. Every 6 weeks I look at all of my likes and try to analyse, why did I like it? What is the structure and how many similar images did I select before? So I came up with about 30 categories or more and this is a kind of map of the images that I respond to on an intuitive level. When I work with models I send them this list and ask them to select 5 categories that are the most interesting to them. Out of those 5 categories they get 5 images each that I collected from tumblr. Then they need to pick the images that they respond to the most. This creates a cross over between their subconscious and mine and it’s from these images that I start creating the staged photography from. For a limited time, it is possible to experience this process first hand, as Boris has kindly donated 3 photo shoots to the campaign. This includes a made-to-measure photo shoot utilising the process outlined above, and a print from the collaboration.Limited edition prints exclusive to the campaignAlso featured as part of Typologien group exhibition of Berlin based photographers, Conor Clarke and Henry Trumble have each donated exclusive limited edition prints of their work to support our campaign. This is a unique opportunity to purchase a work from these emerging photographers who are gaining attention both in Europe and in their respective home countries of New Zealand and Australia. Either piece would make a worthy contribution to an existing collection or make a great initial purchase for anyone looking at collecting photography. 

Melbourne based artist, Kate Robertson, who we will be representing this year at Photo London has also donated the above piece to the campaign. Circle Work 12 (2013) is a photogram, that being an image produced through the photographic process without the use of a camera, produced by hand by the artist in the darkroom. This is a unique silver gelatin print, faithful to the chemistry and history of photography, however leaving no negative or reproduction available. 


First featured in our Frühlings Salon and later in group exhibition Transcendental, Michael Corridore has generously donated the above piece in support of our plans.Untitled 13 (2006) is from the widely celebrated Angry Black Snake, published in Hijacked 2 Australia | Germany, among other significant publications both online and off, this successful body of work also won the 2008 Aperture Portfolio Prize. 
Edition 4 of 13 is produced exclusively at 31,53 x 21cm for the Indiegogo Campaign. 


Photographic Prints from Gallery Director
Director of Galerie Pavlova, Michael Dooney is also offering the above images in an open edition of prints, especially to benefit the crowdfunding campaign. Under the working title of Moving Still Life they are an attempt at showing an old subject in a new and interesting way. 
Screen Printed Galerie Pavlova Eco Tote Bag


   

Fickle Sense, Berlin based screen printer and eco-fashion-blogger, has donated her time and skills to produce these amazing custom Galerie Pavlova screen printed tote bags.All bags are ethically sourced, ecologically produced and hand printed in her studio in Berlin. Available in three colours: mandarin-red, marine-blue and classic black.--------------------The impact of your contribution
By supporting our campaign, you'll be helping secure the future of Galerie Pavlova, and give our represented artists (and future artists) the exposure they deserve.The first year of running the gallery has been met with many challenges and as a young business it will be a long while before it is financially self sufficient. 
Like many of the artists that we support, it is the money that we earn through other means (teaching, consulting, lighting design) that we then invest in the gallery: enabling us to provide a much loved platform for Australian & New Zealand contemporary photography in Europe. 
Other ways you can help
We understand if you're not able to contribute financially, and appreciate all contributions no matter how small they may be. Every little bit counts and will go towards the upkeep of the gallery and our plans for 2015. 

Even if you are not able to contribute, we would really appreciate you spreading the news of Galerie Pavlova and our fund raising campaign. You can also keep up to date on our website and the usual social media avenues:
Official Website: http://www.galeriepavlova.comFollow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/galeriepavlovaLike us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/galeriepavlova

story:
Short Summary

WOW!! WE REACHED OUR INITIAL GOAL IN TEN DAYS!!!!!! THANK YOU!!!!! 

Now, we have the means to make a solid start on our inaugural season as a company. We are incredibly grateful for everyone who has joined with us to make this dream a reality. 

Our initial goal included the absolute necessities to get a company started, our secondary goal includes everything we need for our film production sector and our service programs to expand and THRIVE. Our hope is that we will not have to do another fundraiser for long, long time and will instead become self supporting and you can make that possible!!!! The magic number is $16,000.00! Please contribute if you can!!! You're amazing!

Our new funding wish list is broken down as follows: 


  • Software and educational tools for The Community- $200
  • Supplies for our Title One school programs- $500
  • Workshops with industry professionals for members of our service organization  The Community which we will host free of charge- $500
  • Playbills and printing costs for our first production opening April 2015- $500
  • Professional lighting kit for filmmaking- $800
  • Projector and screen so we can host monthly screenings of CAC films- $1000
  • Federal and State taxes- $1000
  • IndieGOGO fees for additional funds raised- $500
If you are seeing this for the first time please, read below!!! and WELCOME. 

OUR STORY:

The Community Acting Company is a group of nine collaborators dedicated to producing vibrant, truthful, and imaginative works for theatre and film, utilizing the Meisner Technique, as learned at The William Esper Studio.

We believe life must be experienced, which is why creating and observing art with the Meisner Technique is so crucial in today’s society. The Technique allows us to connect directly to the core of humanity through the exploration of new cultures and philosophies. Within that connection, we change our views and behavior in life. We become free, curious, and more engaged. It not only changes us but everyone we touch.

For a company like this to succeed, we had to have an environment where we could feel free to invent, play, and make mistakes which is why we created The Community. It is a service organization with almost 300 members that hosts a variety of performance and social opportunities for actors and artists to collaborate and connect with one another, completely free of charge.

The Community empowers and emboldens artists to live happy, courageous, and productive lives.  We firmly believe, it is important to cultivate and encourage an artist’s success and not perpetuate the idea of the “artist’s plight.”  The Community is a support system for creatives to engage and collaborate with one another to produce a higher quality of work.

We are committed to producing works of art that reflect and serve this mission and these values to the public and we have already booked the venue for our first show at The Producer's Club right off of Times Square in NYC!!! We open April 2015. 

To read more about our mission and the impact your contribution will make, please scroll down!

What We Need & What You Get

To kick start our brand new Company – and support our goals for the coming 2015 season – our funding WAS RAISED!!!! THANK YOU!!! and is broken down as follows:

  • The Producers Club Venue  $2,500
  • Editing software for films $1,200
  • Lighting Designer $1,000
  • Camera w/ lenses $900
  • Licensing rights $800
  • Publicist to spread the word $750
  • Boom and Body mics (sound for film) $500
  • Costumes $500
  • Set Designer $500
  • Rehearsal space rentals for The Community $500
  • Set Pieces $300
  • Taxes, legal fees $300
  • Materials for building sets $250
Many of these funds will go towards creating jobs for designers and technicians, which is pretty cool! Anything over our fundraising goal will go directly towards expanding our free programs and producing more films and plays.
  • Our PERKS (all listed to the side) are designed to be inclusive and enhance the environment of community and connectivity we strive for. We have also named them to reflect concrete items that your contribution will make possible for us. 
  • In the event that we do not reach our goal, although we are very hopeful, our next steps will be to honor our standing financial commitments, as outlined above, in the best way possible. 

  • Priority will be as follows:

    1. The Producers Club Venue- The total cost of this venue was $5000.00, we have already put down half of it as a deposit, the other half we are campaigning for here! 
    2. Licensing rights
    3. Lighting and Set Designers
    4. Film Equipment & Software

    Once fulfilling the above listed items, we will put funds toward space rentals and resources for our free programs. 


The Impact

By contributing to and sharing this campaign, you are becoming an essential part of our community and helping this vision grow, something we cannot do without you! 
You are not only giving us the ability to produce and release our own work, you are giving us the chance to better our lives and empower others to do the same. Your support will enable us to offer live theatre, films, free programs for artists and even outreach programs for New York City youth. 

More importantly, your contribution will help nurture and support proactive compassion and the interaction of global citizens.


Risks & Challenges

Hi friends- Jac here, 

If there is anything I have learned over the last 8 months, it's that if the unexpected can happen, it will. As with any new company, we are aware of the many risks and challenges that will inevitably come our way. 

However, The Community Acting Company is different from many others because we began purely as a service organization for our fellows. That has gives us the amazing resource of a support system like no other: a network of nearly 300 artists who provide an awe inspiring range of connections, expertise and skills. 

I believe the culture of service and support that we cultivate makes us uniquely situated to handle any situation that arises. With so many people working on a solution, whenever a problem does arise, I know we will be able to overcome anything that seems to stand in our way.

Words simply aren't enough to express the gratitude we feel for helping us make a dream into reality. We are all so incredibly grateful for your support.

Thank you!!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, we would LOVE it if you could instead:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign through email, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and word of mouth!!!!
  • Like our fan page on Facebook
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to up our standing on the Indie go go campaign trending page!!
  • if you would like to mail a check or contribute via VENMO please email us at contactthecommunitynyc@gmail.com

Thank you again, we look forward to serving and collaborating with you in the future!

story:
My Story

My name is Anne Woodman. I started making jewelry about 5 years ago and have been slowly but surely building a business out of it. Unfortunately, when I decided to turn this craft into a money making business, I was starting with zero capital. So over the years, I've had to: make a sale - get business cards made, make a sale - get look books printed, make a sale - get some displays, (and the forever) make a sale - get more jewelry supplies to make more stuff! I'm really trying to get out there now, and everything costs money! I just spent every last penny on a trade show in Paris (Bonjour! I'm here now) and I realized that the deadline to apply for the Renegade craft fair is Friday at midnight. I've never done the Renegade and I think I would do really well there. I know I would make  lot of sales, meet some great people, grow the business further. So I went to apply online and they want $400 up front! Imagine my dismay, I am spent, literally.


The Impact

The impact of doing this craft fair without going into debt will mean that I can use the money that is made from this fair to create a "Fair/Show fund" that will be used to attend more and more fairs/shows, grow the fund, grow the business (already going global, people) and you can say that you knew me when and not only that, but you had a part in the success!


What I Need & What You Get

I need $400 by midnight Friday March 4th. Then I need $100 to buy a new table to be used at craft fairs and shows (mine recently gave up after 4 years of abuse), and the remaining money will go into the Fair/Show Fund. If I don't reach my goal in such a short time period, or, if Renegade doesn't accept me, the money will start the afore mentioned Fair/Show Fund. If you donate anything, you will be kept updated via email as to which fairs the money is going to. I already have a list of fairs and shows that I would love to participate in this spring and summer and every single one costs something. Also, check out the amazing perks that I am offering!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you know other artisans/crafters that would like to do these kinds of fairs, many times, they will allow you to share space. I prefer not to share with other jewelry designers but handbags, hats, scarves, shoes, flowers, I'm open to pretty much anything else. It's always more fun to do these things with company. 

Also, if you know of ant fabulous venues that I should apply for, I am always interested in suggestions! I will travel!

story:
the campaign

Hello! My fund raising campaign is about raising the capital to enable a research project at the Glasgow School of Art. A place at the Art School has been awarded to me for the session 2011-2012, with the support of the staff on the MRes Creative Practices course. 


the research

You will be helping to fund research whose aims will be to establish what, if anything, computers can offer art in a post-digital world, and whether the question of authenticity can be satisfied by applying a set of conditions or theory. To answer this question I'll have to gather a history of computer generated art, and the practitioners who made it - the 1950s pioneers of self authored generative systems and variables, mechanical devices and analogue machines. I'll make this information available to all funders as a PDF document, complete with it's rich bibliography.


It will then be possible to ascertain whether this form of art acts as a precursor to the work of the early computer artists who followed, and if software has the ability to express concepts that may not be possible with other media. Can programming a computer to undertake creative instructions merge artistic subjectivity with technical form - or will digital art forever be without aura? In our post-digital future, is it no longer necessary or even desirable to be able to render art as a final tangible artefact with presence or uniqueness?


what I need & what you get

For the first year of research I'll need £2000, or about $3500. With these funds I can embark on a taught programme of research methods including the critical analysis of qualitative and quantatative material allowing me to integrate the rigorous traditions of academic research with the inventiveness of creative practices.


With these skills, I can move forward to examine computer art with a view to critiquing, extracting and applying the most relevant research enquiries and outcomes.


For £10 I will give you a PDF copy of my research findings. £50 will get you a bound hard copy of my research results. £100 will buy you a hard copy and an annual update, via email, of my progress. If you would like to donate £500, I will correspond with you directly 3 times per year, making available all my findings, notes and photographs of any art works I've made which have been influenced by my research findings. If you are kind enough to donate £1000, all of the above will be yours, but I will also gift you an original art work, authored by the results of my research.


other ways you can help

Please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Sharing my details with friends, collegues and family you think may be interested, could help tremendously.


Thank you,

Andy x

story:
When many people think of Japan, they think of Tokyo, Kyoto, or Osaka. I am interested in street photography, which traditionally, would be perfect for the cities, but I prefer to avoid clichés. My project I am pursuing at Studio Kura is a documentary photography series, using the principles of street photography, about rural Japan around the Fukuoka Prefecture.

My process was inspired by a quote from J.R.R. Tolkien where he said, “Not all those who wander are lost.”   When I leave the house there is no agenda, and I don’t visualise photographs in advance of taking them. The destination is one of discovery, and both reveal one’s self, and the soul of the place, in the process of wandering.

We are so busy that we often overlook the beauty of the place we inhabit. Sometimes it takes a fresh set of eyes to notice events, architecture, and culture that many locals would overlook as they have seen them before. I will explore, find, and show the everyday beauty that is all around Fukuoka Prefecture to her residents, and Japanese rural culture to the international community.

The end result will be a number of pieces for exhibition (both in Japan and at Maud Gallery in Brisbane, Australia next year), and a fine art photo book.

This is where I need your help. I've already paid for my flights to Japan, but I need your support to cover my residency fees (¥180,000) and living expenses (¥15,000/week) while I'm in Japan. 

You can find examples of my previous work at www.linseywalker.com

story:
Short Summary

Nosebleed Studio is Sweden's most skilled and productive manga studio. We have been active since 2006 and publish our own work in annual anthologies. 

Our four members are:

  • Joakim Waller, creator of Steam dragon express
  • Natalia Batista, creator of Mjau, A Song for Elise and Sword Princess Amaltea
  • Alice Engström, creator of the upcoming August in June
  • Catarina Batista
From many years of experience we have all gathered a lot of knowledge on coloring and manga illustration. This artbook will capture all that knowledge in mindblowing A4-sized images, tutorials and information about tools and more. 

Manga art is today a Global art form. By backing this project you will not only get nice perks but also be a proud owner of this limited edition artbook, a physical proof of that even in a small country as Sweden there are talented artists with a passion for the Manga art form.


What We Need & What You Get

By selling our previous books we have saved up enough money for part of the printing costs, but we need your help to gather the rest. All the money from this campaign will go to paying for the printing cost of the artbook.


The artbook:
64 pages, 42 of them in color and 22 in black and white
A4 size and with a luxurious partially glossy cover
Contains color artwork, black and white illustrations, artist profiles, tutorials and sketches!


As a thank you for your help you get these nice perks:

  • Backer-chan, a minimum 6 €
    Y    ou get an A5-print in color, printed on glossy photo-paper shipped to your location worldwide!

  • Backer-san, a minimum of 20 €
    You get 2014 Nosebleed Studio Artbook + glossy A5-print shipped to your location worldwide!

  • Backer-senpai, a minimum of 60 €
    You get 2014 Nosebleed Studio Artbook + exclusive A3-print of a picture of your choice from the artbook + glossy A5-print shipped to your location worldwide!

  • Backer-sama, a minimum of 100 €
    You get all perks from the Senpai level + 1h private manga lesson with the artist of your choice either via Skype or in person (in Lund/Stockholm, Sweden)!

  • Backer-dono, a minimum of 400 €
    You get all perks from the Sama level + 1 of these four original artworks:


The Impact

The Nosebleed Studio Artbook of 2014 is a rare collection of Sweden's most talented and well-known manga artists. 

We have produced books and other printed products since 2006 and crowdfunded our latest manga anthology - Nosebleed Studio's Swedish Manga Anthology - with a successfull result! 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread this campaign so that others too may get their hands on this fantastic artbook! 
And why not support this project a second time and get an artbook for a friend aswell? 

Follow the work on the artbook and all our other projects by liking our Facebook page!

Joakim Waller, creator of Steam dragon express
Natalia Batista, creator of Mjau, A Song for Elise and Sword Princess Amaltea
Alice Engström, creator of the upcoming August in June
Catarina Batista
From many years of experience we have all gathered a lot of knowledge on coloring and manga illustration. This artbook will capture all that knowledge in mindblowing A4-sized images, tutorials and information about tools and more. Manga art is today a Global art form. By backing this project you will not only get nice perks but also be a proud owner of this limited edition artbook, a physical proof of that even in a small country as Sweden there are talented artists with a passion for the Manga art form.What We Need & What You GetBy selling our previous books we have saved up enough money for part of the printing costs, but we need your help to gather the rest. All the money from this campaign will go to paying for the printing cost of the artbook.The artbook:64 pages, 42 of them in color and 22 in black and whiteA4 size and with a luxurious partially glossy coverContains color artwork, black and white illustrations, artist profiles, tutorials and sketches!As a thank you for your help you get these nice perks:

story:
Bringing 'Sparks' to Life -

My name is Noah and I'm an artist. I draw, paint, write, and continually immerse myself in just about everything I can creatively! I have been painting for a couple years now and at this point its very raw and unfocused and that is all about to change! After this show I will start doing more master's studies and learning their techniques and even new ones that they weren't even to think about. But since this skill is unfocused and raw, it also has the greatest potential I believe because it's 100% just myself with a few exceptions!

The goal of this campaign is to fund getting prints made for the show! That includes cost of getting them scanned and making Giclee prints of them (meaning they'll be of the highest quality possible). 

This show means a lot to me for the simple fact that it's my first plunge into the art world and showing that I'm actually an artist. The four paintings I have decided to make prints out of mean a great deal to me. The first is one I made for my sister who has passed away a year and a half ago. This is also important because the profit from the show is going to go towards paying funeral costs and things still needing taken care of since her passing. 

I simply just need to fund prints for the show and with your help, you can have some of the art I've created!

Time to break it down in more detail:

  • With making prints I want to make them the highest quality so they are as close to the originals they can be! 
  • For each Painting it will be $50 for scanning. Ontop of that each print will run about $35 each if I order 10 of them (that price comes down if I order more and based on demand from this campaign I can adjust those numbers).
  • I was considering making a bunch of things for this campaign and give a bunch of price points for contribution, but I think I'm just going to keep it simple. I am usually sharing everything on social media on what I am doing but I'm restraining myself from that so that contributors are getting 'special treatment'. This will include various emails about what I am working on for the week as the show approaches and pictures or paintings in progress. There will also be a separate email detailing a few of the paintings and how they've gotten to the point they are at now! 
  • Regardless of if I meet my goal or not, all the funds are going directly to getting the prints made. The show is happening and I need to have something there!

The Impact

Not only will you help build a little more confidence in myself as an artist taking his first steps in the limelight, the difference your contribution will make is pretty immense. I'm lucky and blessed enough to be able to say I love everyday I'm able to wake up and do something that I'm passionate about. But even though I'm lucky enough to be doing this for my life, bills don't stop and I would like to help my parents with bills left from my sister's passing. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You're not required to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can’t help:

  • Sharing this campaign could help out massively! Liking and sharing on Facebook as well as other social media is the easiest and most impactful way to help!
  • You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Hello! I'm Danny, a recent graduate from Circomedia (School for contemporary Circus and Physical Theatre).

Several years ago I made a documentary of myself cycling the length of the UK for Amnesty International. 

This time round I'm going to take an environmental circus/theatre piece I made called "The Ship is Sinking" on a 3000 mile tour around New Zealand - visiting schools to perform and to run workshops. This will happen in Feb-March of 2014. Whist doing this, I'm going to document my travels and send footage back to my UK team. They'll edit and upload weekly videos to youtube and facebook. The episodes will be a great fun way to watch the adventure unfold, hopefully hitting as large an audience as possible and encourage them to donate online to Green Peace.

This fundraising campaign is to help me raise enough money to get to New Zealand and to get some much needed equipment - bike, tent, video camera, food etc

Please be a part of the whole experience by following and liking on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/theshipsinking

The combination of documentary, exploration, performance and workshops offers extra depth to what I'm doing and gives me the best chance to be able to do something both challenging and life changing for the most universal cause.

Have a look at my previous journey at 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gduWeg8jOK0#t=162

story:
Hello fabulous community,

I am David Salazar, aka Poolboy. I am a recent New Orleans transplant from Austin, TX posting on behalf of the New Orleans Burning Community,

We here in NOLA would love to bring our community and art to Flipside this year in the form of a Large-scale monster straight from the swamp!

The MECHA-GATOR is interactive flame effect sculpture that is community operated! it is made from all recycled materials and is nice and blinky!!

Please help us raise funds to bring this project to Flipside 2014!!!!

We are hoping to raise $1500 to cover the cost of transportation to the event and propane for the effect for the entirety of the event,

Our project is already built and ready to go barring these costs.

In addition to good karma and love from the team, we are offering some awesome incentives that include custom hand-molded mardi gras medallions in the shape of the mecha-gator and some awesome stickers from the Mardi Gras krewe that made this amazing sculpture possible!

I personally think this project is fantastic, in that, it brings two amazing burning communities together to celebrate art!

If you can't donate please spread the word for us and try to help us get to our goal!!

Sending Love from NOLA,

Poolboy

story:
Northampton Labour Club is run down, tatty and skint... but we want to keep it going as a community centre, social centre and venue

we are reorganising and shortly a new committe group will be relaunching to appeal to the wider community
A quick cash fix can help it to set up again
Loads of us have enjoyed this place and it would be good if the next generation can do the same...Can you spare a fiver or even a couple of quid to keep this important local centre stay open?
Please chip in if you can, but also support the events and keep an eye out for chances to get involved and help with the relaunch.. .or just pop in for a pint if passing

story:
Created by artists Viviane Le Courtois and Christopher R. Perez, Processus is a shared place for artists to think and make. It includes a multi-use sculpture and wood shop, a darkroom, a clean space for framing and printmaking, and a coffee club/ pop up space. It will open this fall at The Temple, 2400 Curtis St., Denver CO 80205 (entrance on 24th St.) in the RiNo Art District.

Viviane Le Courtois and Christopher R. Perez bring the expertise of all aspects of art, community and life together. They love making objects, growing or transforming things, cooking, walking, traveling, bringing people together and making them think. Viviane Le Courtois is a conceptual and process based artist working primarily with installation, performance, sculpture, fiber arts, ceramic and printmaking. Most of her work over the last 25 years has linked art, life and people. As an educator, curator and organizer of participatory projects, she will give an artistic direction to the space. Christopher R. Perez is a photographer with outstanding experience in both contemporary and alternative photographic processes. He also has over 20 years of experience in art handling, framing, crate building, and wood fabrication. 

"Processus [prɔsesys] is the French word for process, evolution; a group of actions with a common goal; a series of events or a succession of methods.This multi-use spaceis inspired by our art philosophies and way of life. Driven by process and ideas, our works reflect timeless actions and methods as we often go back to the basics. For years, we have dreamed about a place to work, a place to meet new people and share important ideas. We envision a place where everyone can experiment and discover new things." -Viviane Le Courtois

With a focus on handmade objects, Processus will provide tools, assistance and advice for artists to professionally create and display their works.  Regular coffee events, workshops, lectures, and art happenings will activate the space.Your contribution will help:

  • provide professional equipment for artists and other creative individuals to use at Processus
  • help us cover the cost of our tenant finish to make a safer and healthier environment for everyone including electrical, ventilation, dust collecting, plumbing of work sinks, shelving and work surfaces, etc... 
  • provide a year round space to create and exchange ideas at a reasonable cost 

In order to accomplish our start up goals, we need to raise at least $20,000. Additional funds beyond $20,000 would allow us to get some more high tech equipment such as a large format digital printer and a CNC router. As an appreciation for your contribution, you will receive a piece of art or a free service. When I was a child, my father would sell a cow when we did not have any money. In the same way, by offering a piece of art or a service, we wish to get everything we need to open Processus. 

With 50 years of combined experience as artists and art professionals, we will make things happen. This idea has been brewing for years over the dinner table. In the city the size of Denver, there are thousands of artists and individuals who could use Processus. We are starting at an intimate scale (2150 square feet) to succeed, in the hope to grow. Since there are very limited resources for artists in Denver, we hope that you can contribute to make this space a great resource for many and to be a part of an innovative contemporary art space!

If you cannot contribute now, you can also help by:

  • sharing this with your friends on Facebook using the Indigogo share tools on social media or forward to your friends via email.
  • offering free services, volunteer time or in kind donations 
  • purchasing a gift punchcard or a membership in advance or telling people to join. For details, contact us at processusartlife@gmail.com or 303 526 8064  or visit  http://www.processusartlife.com/membership/

story:
Who Am I?

Hello! I am Zoey Gassner. I live in Santa Rosa and am a junior in high school. I have been a part of my school's specialized art program, ArtQuest, for two years. Currently, I am enrolled in two specialties : Digital Arts and Visual Fine Arts. Next year, I will be entering the AP (advanced placement) level - a college prep art class. Since joining this program, I have found what I love - what I want to do. The arts (specifically design) are my passion. I can't see a life without it - without the opportunity to create.

CCA's Pre-College Program & Me (& You!)

I have been accepted into the Graphic Design studio in the California College of the Arts Pre-College Program. It is a month long immersion into a college-level art school environment. On completion, I will have not only gained 3 college credits, but experienced a great growth with my work. To be surrounded by teachers and peers geared towards graphic design, my passion, would be the greatest pleasure and biggest asset for myself and the future I strive for.

I have received a $1000 scholarship based on merit, but I am still in need of the remaining $2000 for the full tuition and fees. My family is only able to afford my housing, leaving me to find other avenues to complete my tuition fees. If I do not reach my funding goal here, all money donated will still be directed towards the program, and I will find a way to make up the rest. So, you! Yes, you, reader of this plea, any donation at all is truly a gift to me and overwhelmingly appreciated! By attending this program, I will take advantage of all it has to offer, and your funding will be put to good, creative use. Thank you, thank you!

story:
(Please follow our progress on the “Updates” tab.)
Poetry, art and art films are like bread to the hungry. They give us the hope and courage to rise to our greatest deeds and act as conscience when we do not rise. We are not only creating a film but a gathering point for conversations that create community to last longer than any art.
Help us produce “To the Diggers”, the second in a collection of four short art films to be shown in a new kind of exhibition. Based upon a poem Mark Turner wrote in 2006, “To the Diggers” asks whether the sights and sounds of public relations will survive to be dug up by future archeologists. This is Film 2 of the FilmGalleryColxn, four short films merging tangible artwork with digital treatment, spoken word with music and sound effects, all in a motion graphics presentation which inspires you to talk about the philosophical and spiritual aspects of life.
When the collection of films is completed the premiere of the films will be a pilot event to test the new exhibition idea, the “film-gallery-café”. The projected time of the pilot event is Spring, 2011. The test event will teach us about opening a permanent venue where art films and the artwork used to make them stimulate significant conversations encouraging people on their journeys toward God. Until then each finished film will help build the support base which will make the premiere a big success and launch development of the “film-gallery-café”.

Background on the Artists:
For some 40 years we, Mark & Donna Turner, have inspired people on five continents through our films, theater and teaching. We founded and still direct Horizon Gate Productions, a 30 year old non-profit arts organization (501c)3). Our career has been dependent upon donations from supporters and in this way we successfully raised a family amid all our art projects and travels. Lately the economy has taken its toll on donors’ ability to give. We must broaden our community to include you and your friends. Please join in helping spread the word about this campaign so we can accomplish the next step in our mission to inspire people.

Funds Needed:
The first 10 people to contribute $10 or more will be listed in the credits of the film as “First Funders”.
You can help make this art film, “To the Diggers”, by sponsoring the poem, sound effects, music, voice, drawings, motion graphics, or release party. Your contributions will help cover our living expenses for about two months, upgrade computers, purchase art materials and purchase an external hard drive to store all the new digital files.
All donations are tax deductible and will be administered through Horizon Gate Productions, a 501c)3, non-profit organization. Project progress reports will be published frequently through our e-newsletter/blog http://horizongate.blogspot.com , Artingle blog http://artingle.blogspot.com , and the updates of this site.

Perks:
Check out the fabulous incentives we offer:
copies of films signed by the artists
signed, dated and framed prints, or originals of art used in the making of the film
signed poetry selected from Mark’s repertoire based on your preference
CD’s especially made for you
the chance for your name to be in the credits of the film!

Background on the Larger Project:
The FilmGalleryColxn is the first wave of a campaign to inspire lots of people. We are producing four art films which will be the core of a growing collection representing many artists exhibited in a film-gallery-café. We dream of people sitting among the films and the art used to make them being inspired to have life-giving conversations. The first art film, “Comforting Hovers” ( http://www.horizongate.org/products/comfortingh... ), is produced and the remaining three are at various stages of development. Each film is another phase building to the final phase: the premiere of the collection in a pilot venue testing our film-gallery-café concept. Each phase is another opportunity for you to participate in the funding and to recruit other supporters.

We founded and still direct Horizon Gate Productions, a 30 year old non-profit arts organization (501c)3).  Our career has been dependent upon donations from supporters and in this way we successfully raised a family amid all our art projects and travels.  Lately the economy has taken its toll on donors’ ability to give.  We must broaden our community to include you and your friends.  Please join in helping spread the word about this campaign so we can accomplish the next step in our mission to inspire people.
Funds Needed:
The first 10 people to contribute $10 or more will be listed in the credits of the film as “First Funders”.
You can help make this art film, “To the Diggers”, by sponsoring the poem, sound effects, music, voice, drawings, motion graphics, or release party. Your contributions will help cover our living expenses for about two months, upgrade computers, purchase art materials and purchase an external hard drive to store all the new digital files.
All donations are tax deductible and will be administered through Horizon Gate Productions, a 501c)3, non-profit organization.  Project progress reports will be published frequently through our e-newsletter/blog http://horizongate.blogspot.com , Artingle blog http://artingle.blogspot.com , and the updates of this site.
Perks:Check out the fabulous incentives we offer:
copies of films signed by the artists
signed, dated and framed prints, or originals of art used in the making of the film
signed poetry selected from Mark’s repertoire based on your preference
CD’s especially made for you
the chance for your name to be in the credits of the film!
Background on the Larger Project:
The FilmGalleryColxn is the first wave of a campaign to inspire lots of people.  We are producing four art films which will be the core of a growing collection representing many artists exhibited in a film-gallery-café.  We dream of people sitting among the films and the art used to make them being inspired to have life-giving conversations.  The first art film, “Comforting Hovers” ( http://www.horizongate.org/products/comfortingh... ), is produced and the remaining three are at various stages of development.  Each film is another phase building to the final phase: the premiere of the collection in a pilot venue testing our film-gallery-café concept.  Each phase is another opportunity for you to participate in the funding and to recruit other supporters.

story:
*UPDATE: Campaign over, but you can still get the book :)*


You can now purchase this book online. Visit my Etsy page for details!

You can also get them for free if you're apart of a non-profit organization. Please email minnie@minniephan.com.

Thanks!

First: I started this campaign will little expectations, but I was completely blown away by the generosity of friends and people around the world. Thank you so much for helping make this project a reality!

Second: On November 22nd, 2013 I was awarded a grant of $500 from the California College of the Arts towards this project. I am so happy to announce that once I reach $2,100 here on Indiegogo, my campaign will be complete and all proceeds after printing and shipping costs will be donated to Direct Relief towards helping Typhoon Haiyan victims.

Third: Thank you everyone for the incredible support!
The book debuted on December 12th and everyone was so thrilled and happy. It was awesome!


----------------------------------

The painting you see above this text is of my parents at a refugee camp in Hong Kong.

23 years ago, my parents became known as 'boat people' and escaped Vietnam in hopes of a brighter future. They were at sea for roughly 30 days before reaching China and then were granted access to America three years later.

My name is Minnie Phan and I was born in the San Francisco Bay Area. I grew up in a household where the past was never spoken of, and my desire for a punk rock life style left my relationship with my parents distant and torn. I rebelled against the culture my parents had given me.

In the summer of 2013, I won a scholarship to visit Vietnam for the first time in 15 years.

What came from this experience was a new understanding of my parents and the stories they left on the shores of Vietnam. 

When I returned to America, I illustrated this trip as my senior Illustration thesis at the California College of the Arts.

The moment I arrived to Saigon, I was labeled “Việt Kiều”, a term used by Vietnamese citizens to refer to Vietnamese people living in other countries. In the United States, I did not feel like an American, and yet in Vietnam, I was not even a true Vietnamese. But this didn't hold me back. My trip transformed into a journey about my cultural identity and the importance of family. I went 21 years of my life disliking my own skin. But after this journey, I was changed.

(This is me with my extended family in Hue, Vietnam)

But I need help funding the printing of this book

It is thanks to my parents that I am living in the United States and am able to obtain a college degree. However, my family has always struggled financially, and I've been funding my own education from the very beginning. I've written countless scholarship essays, and every summer I work at least 2 jobs to pay my tuition. This book is very special to me.. but also very costly. I want to surprise my parents and say thank you, but I do not have the heart to burden them with financial need. This project has been a secret for the last 4 months, and I would like to surprise them at my thesis reception.

I have roughly a week to get funding for this project

Out of shyness, I was afraid to try an Indiegogo campaign. But I love my parents and my family so much.. I told myself I had to at least try. So in order to print my books on time, I will need to raise the funds within a week. Any amount helps. Even a forward via e-mail is appreciated. My ultimate goal is to also print this book in Vietnamese, so that I can reach my extended family as well.

Even if you can't contribute, please get the word out!

Thank you so much for your time and consideration. To see more of my art, please go to minniephan.com

story:
Summary

Hello friends! My name is Shanta Ambady and I am an artist based out of Detroit, Michigan. After a few years exploring different avenues of creation (from burlesque, sideshow and fire performing, to the culinary arts, to painting, and anything else I could get myself into), I've found that ultimately I'd like to focus my attention on ceramics and illustration. Until I can find a way to get back into school, I've been seeking alternative ways of education and now I have a HUGE opportunity to work alongside two very influential artists – Ayumi Horie and Andy Brayman -  at a renowned ceramic arts foundation! Of course, this winter has been a rough one for all of us (especially in Detroit), so a pothole-induced flat tire here, some soaring heating bills there, a few doctors visits…and poof! There went the money I was saving to take this class. 


However, I’m not giving up just yet! I believe in the power of community. Just as I have donated to causes and charities whenever I could afford to, I am now asking for help to reach my own goals. This workshop is focused on learning diverse techniques of making water-slide decals for firing onto ceramic ware - including silk-screening, laser printing and digital printing. They will also go over different methods of illustration in Photoshop and Illustrator, which would be incredibly beneficial to me. I can’t express how excited I would be to learn more ways to combine my two favorite mediums and open up more possibilities for my work (not to mention, I would be pretty geeked to meet these two cutting edge artists!)

The Archie Bray Foundation itself is a nonprofit organization dedicated to emerging and established ceramic artists and also listed on the National Register of Historic Places. This could potentially be another huge stepping stone in my career, and a much needed boost of inspiration. Any small amount will get me closer and would be infinitely appreciated.


What We Need & What You Get

My modest estimate is about $2,200 for the trip. This covers tuition for the class ($795), my housing for two weeks which will thankfully include a shuttle bus to the foundation ($780) and a round trip flight (approximately $600 – since I have specific dates, I don’t have a lot of flexibility in finding cheaper flights or deals.)

All other expenses, such as food and purchasing clay I will try to fund myself.


Because you are so generous in donating to my cause, these are some gifts I will create in return!


$10 – a personal thank you on my page as well as a weird, hand drawn postcard from my travels! 

$20 – all of the above plus a handmade terracotta ceramic skull magnet 

$50 – all of the above plus a handmade owl mug – this is a brand new item in the works! Cast in white stoneware and dipped in a food safe glaze.

$150 – all of the above plus a creepy hand painted ceramic baby doll head planter cast from a vintage mold - also a brand new item! 

$500 – all of the above, and I will create a one-of-a-kind piece for you at Archie Bray using the decals I designed from the workshop (4 available)




So what happens if I don’t reach my goal?

This workshop is a very rare opportunity, but if I don’t make the goal….well, I have learned that everything happens (or doesn’t happen) for a reason. Luckily, there are always other art centers offering classes and I can use these funds towards a second choice of workshop later in the year.


The Impact

The impact of this trip would be immeasurable. Last year I received a scholarship for a workshop at Anderson Ranch Arts Center and learned more in two weeks than I could in a whole semester, and had the best experience of my life. I think visiting the Archie Bray Foundation and taking this specific workshop would not only push me forward as an artist, but would also revive my spirit after a very harsh winter. If this campaign is successful…I just couldn't put my gratitude into words.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t donate, your emotional support is still enough! Times are tough, but it doesn't cost a penny to share this with your friends or anyone that would be interested in helping my cause!  You can use the indiegogo share tools to share this on your social media of choice. Thanks again for your support!

story:
I'm sure you've seen the never ending bad news~
We are being bombarded by constant fear.

No, the world hasn't gotten darker.
The truth is: We live is a time of great prosperity!


Thanks to the internet, we have come to see that our media is being controlled as well as our politicians....

Student debt is at an all time high, while job rates are at an all time low.

Many politicians/banks may not be concerned about our futures but there are many people who are.


The Solution?

Entrepreneurship! (self employment!) , teamwork and networking.

Thanks to the internet, we are able to reach a global audience and there is no better way to promote products then word of mouth.

This is what the Cosmic Soup project is all about!

~


How your donations will be used:


Funds will be used to purchase products from our network of digital/local entrepreneurs. (you will be giving them jobs)

In turn, we will be using these things to make gift baskets, to donate back to you for your donations.


~~~~~~
The reason we have set out to find solutions:

While many of us are trapped in a never ending cycle of bills, its difficult to stay on top of all the things that govern our lives.
The world has changed and its time the old systems changed to fit our busy lives.


We wish to reunite family's, and promote a healthier/happier world.

It is those with a few dollars to spare that have the power to decide how the market will grow and evolve over the next few years.

Together we can unite with others who have been building solutions and promote their work as well.
~

Conclusion


The old ways are no longer working, its time we use our creativity and love to change the world by looking at the problems that exist in society no one is talking about.



We each deserve an equal opportunity to build out dreams.
Together we are creating the solutions.


We are fighting for the right to healthy life.


Follow us on our Blog:

~ If you wish to join the Cosmic soup project:
please e-mail : Keirani.cosmicsoup@gmail.com

~
If your a musician and are wanting to share your music with the world.
Please visit our "we are the music" facebook page.



Thank you for all your support!

All jobs created from donations will be documented on our blog so everyone can see your donations in action.


Join us on

Twitter:
Sonya-(keirani)
Chad-




Sonya's Cosmic Shop- (Shop where my personal creations are shared)

story:
Hi Brandon Hawk Fans (and haters!)  It was just my 42nd Birthday....  I have been planning a tattoo for 3 years, and now is the TIME!  Many of you have heard me talk about it.  I have found the right artist and am ready to make it a reality.  I thought it would be extra special if it was a gift from my fans...  I love you guys!

   To my haters, hit me with your best "he's a douchbag comments" that you can.  I love it!

   CHAIRTY donation??  Any amount that I raise OVER my $1000 goal, I will split at least 50% (or more) to be donated to Equality Park Pride Center here in Ft Lauderdale.  I like to support the local gay community and outreach programs that support me.

  What are you getting a tattoo of??  The design will go from ankle to shoulder.  I am keeping the actual tattoo a secret.  My artist, Stevie Moon, is making it a one of a kind piece.  The actual tattoo will take about two years to complete and cost WAY more than this start up amount.... 

   Why are you asking for money? Owen and I recently relocated to South FL and I am working in the real estate market here.  After two years building my clients and career in another state, I am back to the beginning with meeting new clients and getting referrals.  This career takes a little time to get going when you move.  I plan to pay for the majority of this ink....but I thought my fans might want to kick it off for me..

    If you need to buy or sell a home ANYWHERE in the US or abroad...let this fun and friendly retired porn star help!

Thank you guys - ALL donations greatly appreciated!!  -Brandon

story:
MOTIF

À notre plus grande surprise, nous, les 15 finissants de l'École de danse contemporaine de Montréal sommes invités à reprendre la pièce "Avant les gens mouraient", crée par le collectif (La) Horde dans le cadre du Festival Les Denses Journées de la Danse 2015, à Paris les 8 et 9 mai.

VOTRE SOUTIEN 

Nous sollicitons votre aide afin d'obtenir une valeur ajoutée sur notre déplacement vers la ville lumière. Ce projet nous tient tous à cœur et notre mobilisation à le réaliser en est la preuve. 
Le montant de fonds amassés sera un appui non négligeable même si nous ne parvenons pas à atteindre notre objectif. 

L'IMPACT DU PROJET

C'est un magnifique projet professionnel pré-diplôme qui aura pour but de nous placer dans la plus pure réalité du métier et les conditions de travail d'un interprète professionnel. C'est de plus une première expérience internationale. 
En réalisant ce projet nous allons faire face à plusieurs éléments techniques qui compose la vie d'artiste et lui confère tout son épanouissement. Nous sommes des bourgeons sur le point d'éclore. 
Une très belle opportunité pour conforter nos choix de carrière future.

DESCRIPTIF DE LA PIÈCE

AVANT LES GENS MOURAIENT

Création originale pour l'École de Danse Contemporaine de Montréal

Pièce chorégraphique pour les 15 danseurs finissants de L’École Contemporaine de Danse de Montréal développée autour du mouvement Mainstream Hardcore en réinterprétant les gestes du Jump Style, du Hard Jump et du Hakken.

Mise en scène, dramaturgie et chorégraphie : (LA) HORDE
Marine Brutti / Jonathan Debrouwer / Arthur Harel / Céline Signoret

Composition musicale : Guillaume Rémus

Costumes : Marie-Claude Jabert

Répétitrice : Hélène Leclair

Éclairage : Thomas Godefroid

Interprètes : Guillaume Archambault-Lelièvre, Catherine Dagenais-Savard, Salina Léna Demnati, Camille Dubé Bouchard, Camille Gachot, Sofia Olivia Garon Orellana, Naomi Hilaire, Audray Julien, German Martinez, Justine Parisien-Dumais, Julie Robert, Sovann Rochon-Prom Tep, Samantha Savard-Lamothe, Stefania Skoryna, Heidi Trudeau

Directrice artistique et des études de l'École de danse contemporaine de Montréal : Lucie Boissinot

Production : École de Danse Contemporaine de Montréal, Conseil des Arts et des Lettres du Québec, Les Pépinières Européennes pour Jeunes Artistes, l'Office Franco Québécois pour la Jeunesse, Les Offices Jeunesse Internationaux du Québec, La Mairie de Paris.


ARTICLES PUBLIÉS
http://quebec.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/12/17/avant-gens-mourraient-entrevues_n_6343344.html?utm_hp_ref=divertissement
http://www.localgestures.com/dance/la-meute-avant-les-gens-mouraient-une-critique
http://www.ledevoir.com/culture/danse/426912/un-cru-d-automne-dans-le-vent-choregraphique

LIENS CONNEXES

http://www.collectiflahorde.com/

http://www.edcmtl.com/
