story:
We're five architectural designers working with a composer, and we've been given a major square in the middle of London for a day.

Hugh, Catrina, Freddy, Kevin and Omar are the founding members of Ada, a Bloomsbury-based collective of professional artists and architectural designers who work together to create spectacles of forward-looking architecture. Ada believe that by combining individuals who are the best in their field from different disciplines, the most aesthetic and intellectually stimulating results can be achieved. Since early 2012 the collective has been working closely with local organisations to produce interactive architectural pieces. Site-specific works have been installed at a number of major local events, including The A Boards at Bloomsbury Fete (2012) and the Icarus project at Bloomsbury Festival (2012).

We're working with composer Adam Donen. His last site specific performance piece, Jokasta: A Puppet Opera, sold out an 8 day run in London's Abney Park Cemetery. His last album, Vampires, a collaboration with Grammy-nominated Robert Harder, was released on the German Songs&Whispers imprint, and has drawn extensive praise both live and on record across Europe. His next piece, Bernhard, a (second) collaboration with The Cure's Roger O'Donnell, will be performed in the UK and Germany by the world-renowned Wurtemmburg Chamber Orchestra of Heilbronn this October.

Bedford Square is right next to Tottenham Court Road, and we’ve been approached to produce the headline piece of the Bloomsbury Summer Fete on the 14th of June at 1 in the afternoon.

So what we want to do is...

We want to fuse architecture with music and performance, and create the first ever dramatic piece (to our knowledge) with a STAGE as lead actor.

Europa is a musical and dramatic work inspired by the current Euro-crisis, seen through the prism of Brecht’s idea that a stage defines action more than the actors which perform upon it.

With your help, we're going to produce a bunch of apparently separate artworks, and have them 'subsume' the Europa piece while it happens. This may sound complex... stay with us here... 

We want to fill the square with interactive architecture – there will be see-saws, slides and tables all of which will be used by around 3000 people that will be drawn to the festival. They'll all be beautiful and functional, but also built very cunningly so that at lunchtime they can take part in the main performance of Europa.

How it's going to work

Europa will start with an orchestra and choir on a very small stage in the middle of the square. But while the music plays, stagehands and actors will begin to bring these pieces towards the stage and connect them, so that the pieces that were, only moments before, being used as board games and seats, become an expanded stage, and the stage grows to 6 times its original size. These elements will then 'perform' as part of the piece.

The effect of an apparently separate artwork at the same festival ‘subsuming’ and ‘defining’ the musical piece is a perfect echo of the themes Europa explores, taking the piece beyond aural entertainment and into the realms of ‘learning play’, where the audience will find their experience of a work redefined completely by things at first seemingly extraneous to the work.

The ability of objects to define experience is Ada’s interest as architectural designers: with this in mind – we will collaborate on expanding the dramatic aspects of the piece to make use of the objects as performers.

This collaboration will also connect two events occurring concurrently in Bloomsbury: the London Festival of Architecture and Donen’s premiere, and can be judged by the degree to which cross-pollination between these events occurs. It will prove the value of cultural events in the Bloomsbury area and prove that the use of public spaces in Bloomsbury for cultural events is not just viable, but hugely successful.

Most excitingly, it will be a surprising and powerful link of two apparently separate works, and will excite a musical audience about the dramatic possibilities of architecture, and an architectural audience about the interaction with music.

What We Need

We need to buy fabrics and materials. We need to make costumes for our actors, (both animate and inanimate). We need time to create this structure, and time to rehearse it. It's an ambitious undertaking, and while the Bloomsbury Fete are helping us out, their budget stretches only so far, and not so far as what we want to do with this piece. We’re asking the Arts council for funding, we’re asking sponsors for funding, and most importantly, we’re asking you.

To break it down in more detail:

The total cost of the project (including support provided ‘in kind’) is £18,000.

The Midtown Business Club (‘MBC’), for whom the stage is being provided, are very keen to support this performance and stage as the artistic centrepiece of the Fete. To this end, they have secured confirmed sponsorship in kind from Mace Construction, who will provide materials for all architectural designs free of charge (estimated value of £8,000).

MBC have already provided a workshop space free of charge for construction and combined rehearsals with the musicians and actors, beginning 20 May. They are also providing £1500, with which to hire a basic stage structure. And this is where you come in, and provide the funds necessary to build out this stage to its full potential.

If we raise more than £2,000, it will go directly to improving the quality of the piece further - paying for more rehearsals, more ornate costumes, and bigger robot drummers (REALLY). We'd love it if this happened. We want to create something magical, and huge.

What's on offer

We're expecting that everyone who sees the piece is going to want to remember it, and we have plenty of gifts for all ranges of donations.

These range from Donen's CDs and Europa posters to beautiful riso prints (from A4 to A1), ranging right the way up to OWNING a functional piece of the stage after performance (whether a see-saw, steps or similar) and bound editions of the final Europa score (limited to 8 copies!) signed by all the lead musicians, performers and designers. We're also providing the opportunity for you to see the pieces in action, and visits during rehearsals (during either the first or second week of June).

Above all, though, you'll be able to watch a major piece of public drama, mixing all manner of disciplines, and know that you participated directly in its creation.

The Impact

To our knowledge, this is the only piece ever written with an inanimate object as the Lead Actor. It's ridiculously ambitious. And just the sort of thing that Indiegogo was made for. 

The introduction of the architectural medium would greatly enhance the artistic strength of this commission (and drastically increase the likelihood of repeat performances, and provide wonderful showcase material).

Other Ways You Can Help

Not working through major arts organisations (one day we'll have a piece at the Royal Opera House, but we're young, and sadly that'll probably be a while yet), we work on a shoestring, but that string needs lengthening. Any help would be received more gratefully than you can imagine. Whatever way, please spread the word about this. Tweet if that's your thing, Facebook, blog, get in touch, talk to us.

And finally if you're in London, come along, play with the architecture, and watch the show - it's free. 14 June. 1pm.

With your help, we're going to produce a bunch of apparently separate artworks, and have them 'subsume' the Europa piece while it happens. This may sound complex... stay with us here... 
We want to fill the square with interactive architecture – there will be see-saws, slides and tables all of which will be used by around 3000 people that will be drawn to the festival. They'll all be beautiful and functional, but also built very cunningly so that at lunchtime they can take part in the main performance of Europa.

How it's going to work
Europa will start with an orchestra and choir on a very small stage in the middle of the square. But while the music plays, stagehands and actors will begin to bring these pieces towards the stage and connect them, so that the pieces that were, only moments before, being used as board games and seats, become an expanded stage, and the stage grows to 6 times its original size. These elements will then 'perform' as part of the piece.
The effect of an apparently separate artwork at the same festival ‘subsuming’ and ‘defining’ the musical piece is a perfect echo of the themes Europa explores, taking the piece beyond aural entertainment and into the realms of ‘learning play’, where the audience will find their experience of a work redefined completely by things at first seemingly extraneous to the work.
The ability of objects to define experience is Ada’s interest as architectural designers: with this in mind – we will collaborate on expanding the dramatic aspects of the piece to make use of the objects as performers.
This collaboration will also connect two events occurring concurrently in Bloomsbury: the London Festival of Architecture and Donen’s premiere, and can be judged by the degree to which cross-pollination between these events occurs. It will prove the value of cultural events in the Bloomsbury area and prove that the use of public spaces in Bloomsbury for cultural events is not just viable, but hugely successful.
Most excitingly, it will be a surprising and powerful link of two apparently separate works, and will excite a musical audience about the dramatic possibilities of architecture, and an architectural audience about the interaction with music.

What We Need
We need to buy fabrics and materials. We need to make costumes for our actors, (both animate and inanimate). We need time to create this structure, and time to rehearse it. It's an ambitious undertaking, and while the Bloomsbury Fete are helping us out, their budget stretches only so far, and not so far as what we want to do with this piece. We’re asking the Arts council for funding, we’re asking sponsors for funding, and most importantly, we’re asking you.
To break it down in more detail:
The total cost of the project (including support provided ‘in kind’) is £18,000.
The Midtown Business Club (‘MBC’), for whom the stage is being provided, are very keen to support this performance and stage as the artistic centrepiece of the Fete. To this end, they have secured confirmed sponsorship in kind from Mace Construction, who will provide materials for all architectural designs free of charge (estimated value of £8,000).  MBC have already provided a workshop space free of charge for construction and combined rehearsals with the musicians and actors, beginning 20 May. They are also providing £1500, with which to hire a basic stage structure. And this is where you come in, and provide the funds necessary to build out this stage to its full potential.
If we raise more than £2,000, it will go directly to improving the quality of the piece further - paying for more rehearsals, more ornate costumes, and bigger robot drummers (REALLY). We'd love it if this happened. We want to create something magical, and huge.

What's on offer
We're expecting that everyone who sees the piece is going to want to remember it, and we have plenty of gifts for all ranges of donations.
These range from Donen's CDs and Europa posters to beautiful riso prints (from A4 to A1), ranging right the way up to OWNING a functional piece of the stage after performance (whether a see-saw, steps or similar) and bound editions of the final Europa score (limited to 8 copies!) signed by all the lead musicians, performers and designers. We're also providing the opportunity for you to see the pieces in action, and visits during rehearsals (during either the first or second week of June).
Above all, though, you'll be able to watch a major piece of public drama, mixing all manner of disciplines, and know that you participated directly in its creation.
The Impact
To our knowledge, this is the only piece ever written with an inanimate object as the Lead Actor. It's ridiculously ambitious. And just the sort of thing that Indiegogo was made for. 
The introduction of the architectural medium would greatly enhance the artistic strength of this commission (and drastically increase the likelihood of repeat performances, and provide wonderful showcase material).
Other Ways You Can Help
Not working through major arts organisations (one day we'll have a piece at the Royal Opera House, but we're young, and sadly that'll probably be a while yet), we work on a shoestring, but that string needs lengthening. Any help would be received more gratefully than you can imagine. Whatever way, please spread the word about this. Tweet if that's your thing, Facebook, blog, get in touch, talk to us.
And finally if you're in London, come along, play with the architecture, and watch the show - it's free. 14 June. 1pm.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Tamzin Haughton, I am an experienced music video, drama and fashion film producer, director and photographer. I am completing my Masters degree at London College of Fashion, specializing in Photography and Fashion Film.

Symbols of Transformation is a pop-up exhibition of portraits of people with a material object which represents their own personal, positive moment of transformation. The photographs are accompanied by their words.  The exhibition and catalogue will raise awareness and funds for the kids charity Facing The World.  The charity provides transformative plastic and cranial surgery to children in the Third World, who may not otherwise have access to it.

I became aware of the charity whilst waiting for my boyfriend in a hospital, he had been the victim of an unprovoked attack and had sustained serious wounds to his face.  I saw a poster for Facing The World and I was inspired and moved by the work and the difference Facing the World makes to these children's lives.

My work and research for my Masters is all about transformation, I believe that all of us should have the opportunity to make positive personal transformations in our own lives and I have produced a body of work which I hope to inspire people.

What We Need & What You Get

I am looking to raise $3500 to print and frame the large scale prints and print catalogues for the pop up exhibition.  The prints will be auctioned to raise funds and awareness of the charity, with all profits going to the charity.

Rewards for your support include a beautifully printed catalogue of the series, small and large exhibition prints, your name in the acknowledgements of the catalogue and your own portrait sitting and print.

The Impact

Facing The World would like to raise their profile in the USA and the first of the pop up exhibitions will be in Los Angeles.  By supporting the campaign at this stage you will enable me to complete my project.  I have been taking this series of portraits since early 2012 and it has been a wonderful journey for me, I have been very inspired and moved by people's stories of transformation and I hope you will enable me to complete this project. This will be my first photographic exhibition.

Other Ways You Can Help

I really appreciate your support in whatever way you can, please let people know about this project and share the link.  

Best wishes,

Tamzin

story:
Une mosaïque d'eau pour une cause

***English will follow.

Avec le soutien de :

Le projet

Afin de sensibiliser le grand public sur les enjeux mondiaux liés à l’eau, l'artiste Belo créera une image composée de 66 000 verres d'eau de pluie colorée simulant les niveaux d'impuretés trouvées dans l'eau partout sur la planète. Cette œuvre majeure,  de 3 600 pieds carrés représentant un enfant dans le ventre maternel, mettra l’accent sur l’essentialité de l’eau pour tout être vivant, avant même sa naissance. Les buts poursuivis par 66 000 sont multiples : relever le défi artistique et matériel de la réalisation d’une œuvre de cette envergure et conscientiser la population aux conséquences dramatiques du manque d’accessibilité à l’eau potable.

66 000 verres comme autant de souhaits pour un monde où la problématique de l’accessibilité à l’eau potable serait chose du passé.

L’artiste

Belo, un artiste multidisciplinaire, a développé une technique unique et complexe, qui confère à ses œuvres un aspect tridimensionnel et texturé invitant au toucher. Il compose l'image en fusionnant au canevas des milliers de pièces de peinture acrylique miniatures. Une fois assemblées, de 300 à 600 heures plus tard, ces pièces nous révèlent le thème principal de l’œuvre en un univers tridimensionnel fascinant.

En 2010, Belo se voit décerner le Grand Prix du Jury au Festival International Montréal en Arts (FIMA). Ses œuvres ont été exposées à Montréal, New York et en Espagne.

De la toile murale, Belo adaptera son procédé à la réalisation d’une image plus grande que nature. Cette mosaïque monumentale conçue grâce à l’accumulation de milliers de contenants identiques emplis d’eau colorée donnera une nouvelle perspective à la profondeur de ses œuvres.

Le rayonnement

Compte-tenu de la nature éphémère de cette œuvre performative et du caractère universel de la thématique de l'eau, une documentation et une diffusion grand public est indissociable du projet. Une vidéo d’art, un site Internet immersif, une occupation des réseaux sociaux, un documentaire et une diffusion en galerie sont prévus. Une aide au financement permettra ainsi de rejoindre différents publics sur plusieurs plateformes.

L’œuvre performative est prévue pour septembre 2012 et la vidéo d'art sera dévoilée au grand public via Internet dans le cadre de la Journée mondiale de l’eau, le 22 mars 2013.

Comment vous pouvez nous aider

Nous cherchons à combler un manque à gagner de 10 000$ pour boucler un budget d'environ 40 000$.

Dans la phase de planification du projet, nous avons contacté un certain nombre d’entreprises et d’organisations à Montréal afin d’explorer les possibilités de partenariats. Nous avons obtenu l’appui de plusieurs d’entre elles, dont notamment pour l’approvisionnement de quelques verres à café, la location d’un espace de 5 000 pieds carrés, la fourniture d’équipement et la production de la vidéo d’art.

Les fonds amassés serviront à couvrir les dépenses pour :

L’œuvre performative (mosaïque d’eau) :

  • achat de verres à café en carton (les verres seront réutilisés ou recyclés par la suite);
  • achat de matériel de production;
  • service de traiteur pour nos généreux bénévoles et notre équipe de production;
  • frais administratifs.

La vidéo d’art :

  • location d’équipement vidéo et d’éclairage;
  • développement d’une présence Web pour héberger la vidéo d’art, informer la population des enjeux mondiaux liés à l’eau et présenter la liste des partenaires et commanditaires du projet.

Nous vous présentons 9 manières distinctes de contribuer au projet en achetant un des lots (perks) à la droite de l'écran.

66,000 sera la plus importante mosaïque artistique d’eau au monde. Vous pouvez en faire partie et faire la différence!

Si nous n’atteignons pas notre objectif, nous procéderons tout de même à la réalisation du projet mais nous ne parviendrons pas à créer l’impact souhaité.

D’autres façons de nous aider

Si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer financièrement à notre projet, nous vous invitons tout de même à partager par courriel ou via les médias sociaux le lien de notre campagne afin d’augmenter notre visibilité.

Merci pour votre appui!

Facebook : www.facebook.com/66000belo

Twitter : www.twitter.com/66000belo

 

************************************************************************

66,000, a water mosaic with a cause

With the support of:

The Project

To raise awareness among the general public about the global clean water crisis, the artist Belo will create an image composed of 66,000 cups of colored rainwater simulating levels of impurities found in water all over the planet. This major work of 3,600 square feet, representing a fetus in the maternal womb, will emphasize the necessity of water, even before birth, for each living person. The goals of 66,000 are many: taking up the artistic and material challenges inherent to this monumental production, and informing the public of the dramatic consequences of a lack of drinkable water.

66,000 cups with as many wishes for a world where the lack of access to clean water will be a thing of the past.

The Artist

Belo, a mixed media artist, developed a unique and complex technique, which gives his works a tridimensional and textured appearance inviting the onlooker to touch its surfaces. He composes his image by joining thousands of miniature pieces of acrylic paint to his canvas. Once they are joined, 300 to 600 hours later, these pieces reveal the main theme of the work in a fascinating tridimensional universe.

In 2010, Belo won the Grand Prize of the Jury at the Montreal International Art Festival (FIMA). His works have been seen in Montreal, New York and Spain.

From his wall canvases, Belo will adapt his artistic process to the production of a larger-than-life image. This monumental mosaic will be created from the collection of thousands of identical containers filled with colored water which will give a new deeper perspective to his work.

The Impact

Considering the fleeting and ephemeral nature of this artistic performance, and the universal water theme having inspired the artist, the documentation and large scale diffusion of this project is crucial. An art video, an immersive Internet site, social media participation, a documentary and a gallery showing are foreseen. Financial aid will allow the work to be experienced by a varied public on many levels.The artistic performance is scheduled to take place in September 2012 and the art video will be presented to the public via Internet on World Water Day (March 22, 2013).

What We Need

We have set our campaign goal at an achievable $10,000, a figure that covers one-fourth of our expenses. 

In the course of our project planning, we have reached out to a number of companies and organizations in Montreal to explore potential partnerships. One of them has agreed to help us by supplying 1,000 coffee cups, an other by making available a 5,000 square foot space and others by lending the team some equipment and producing the art video.

Funds raised with your generous donations will go towards the:

Artistic performance (water mosaic): 

  • purchasing the remaining cardboard coffee cups (cups will be reused or recycled afterwards);
  • purchasing production supplies;
  • catering for our generous volunteers and production crew;
  • administration fees.

Art video:

  • renting video and lighting equipment;
  • developing an Internet presence to host the art video, to inform the public about the global clean water crisis and to list all partners and sponsors of the project.

Check out our Perks on the right of the page to contribute.

66,000 will be the worlds largest artistic water mosaic. You can be a part of it and make a difference! 

If the goal is not met, the project will still proceed; but we will be unable to make the impact this artwork and important cause needs. 

Other Ways You Can Help

It’s not just about funding, you can help by spreading the word.

Thank you so much for getting involved! 

Facebook : www.facebook.com/66000belo

Twitter : www.twitter.com/66000belo

 

 

Video / Vidéo:                                       Special thanks to / Un merci spécial à:

story:
We're Taking This Show On The Road!

Last summer, The Fully Functional Cabaret was born. Two years in the making, one year in full-tilt production, this all-trans-woman-produced theatrical work was more than song, dance, and tear-away genitalia. It was a moving, transformative love letter to and from trans womanhood.

We made a work that did more than make art, it really felt like a ground-breaking piece of activism. And it only had a two-day run. So we're bringing it back to life!

Our brilliant cast/creators (Star Amerasu, Ryka Aoki, Annie Danger, Red Durkin, Bryn Kelly, and Shawna Virago) live in San Francisco, Los Angeles, and New York City, so every time we put this work out in the world, we have to fund raise. Additionally, we are making art that respects our casts' stories and that, to us, means we would like to be paid for our efforts. Or at least, not lose money for doing important work.

One quite common experience of trans womanhood is isolation. This is our go at peeling back that veil. Please help us take this show on the road!

The Full Breakdown:

We need $2500 dollars to make this show fly high.

Getting our cast eastward is no easy task. In fact, it's costing us nearly $1600. Sure, we get free peanuts and soda on the way, but the cost is still high.

Additionally, we are renting theater space in NYC ($350). We will be printing programs, T-tickets, and Certificates of Good Personhood ($75 per show X 5+ shows = almost $400). We also need to make shirts and DVDs to sell at our merch table, a significant part of our income/our pay for doing this work.

We are sponsored by a small number of college tour stops and by our merchandise table, but we need this money to complete our budget.

Key to the ethics at this show's heart is respecting the stories of the people involved, and in a world where trans women are seriously economically disadvantaged, that can mean paying them. Any money we make over our goal goes straight into our performers' pockets.

Prizes and Thanks!

  • A donation of $20 gets you glossy photo of the cast!
  • A donation of $35 garners the a handcrafted, artisanal, local thank you note!
  • A donation of $75 comes with a CD by Shawna Virago!
  • A donation of $100 gets you a Fully Functional Cabaret t-shirt in a special Donor Blue!
  • A donation of $250 will bring you stimulating, philosophical tea time with Annie Danger! Ask her anything! (Skype/gChat if necessary)
  • A donation of $500 or comes with everything listed above AND a specialty ringtone recorded by the entire cast (mp3 available if necessary)

The Impact

Supporting The Fully Functional Cabaret supports the radical expansion of what trans allyship, trans community, and queer art can look like. We are looking to feed a number of birds with this bush, not the least of which inlcude: creating more brilliant trans culture, putting the 'T' more firmly back into 'LGBT', challenging meanings of allyhood and spectatorship, healing through group performance, experimenting with utopic performatives, paying trans women (!), and planting a seed that can flourish into a nationally-touring show.

Annie Danger, the facilitator of this project, has a long and committed history to transformative (no pun intended...much) performance that doesn't lose a single ounce of fun and humor for all its earnesty. She has brought the world multiple full-length shows, including It's That Easy! With Terry VanWeen!, a motivational seminar for the revolution, and The Great Church of the Holy Fuck, a queer spiritual service about the power and healing in deeply queer sex and bodylove.

Other Ways You Can Help

Ooh! I don't have a ton of money either. If you don't have $5, $10, or $1000 for this campaign, no problem! Please:
  • Pass the word on! Tell your friends! Spread this campaign ALL OVER Facebutt, Twitter, and the rest of the internets!
  • If you're in the Bay Area this July, just come and see it!
  • If you're in the Bay Area this June, help us build sets and flyer!
  • Love trans women!

We need $2500 dollars to make this show fly high.
Getting our cast eastward is no easy task. In fact, it's costing us nearly $1600. Sure, we get free peanuts and soda on the way, but the cost is still high.
Additionally, we are renting theater space in NYC ($350). We will be printing programs, T-tickets, and Certificates of Good Personhood ($75 per show X 5+ shows = almost $400). We also need to make shirts and DVDs to sell at our merch table, a significant part of our income/our pay for doing this work.
We are sponsored by a small number of college tour stops and by our merchandise table, but we need this money to complete our budget.
Key to the ethics at this show's heart is respecting the stories of the people involved, and in a world where trans women are seriously economically disadvantaged, that can mean paying them. Any money we make over our goal goes straight into our performers' pockets.
Prizes and Thanks!

A donation of $20 gets you glossy photo of the cast!
A donation of $35 garners the a handcrafted, artisanal, local thank you note!
A donation of $75 comes with a CD by Shawna Virago!
A donation of $100 gets you a Fully Functional Cabaret t-shirt in a special Donor Blue!
A donation of $250 will bring you stimulating, philosophical tea time with Annie Danger! Ask her anything! (Skype/gChat if necessary)
A donation of $500 or comes with everything listed above AND a specialty ringtone recorded by the entire cast (mp3 available if necessary)



The Impact
Supporting The Fully Functional Cabaret supports the radical expansion of what trans allyship, trans community, and queer art can look like. We are looking to feed a number of birds with this bush, not the least of which inlcude: creating more brilliant trans culture, putting the 'T' more firmly back into 'LGBT', challenging meanings of allyhood and spectatorship, healing through group performance, experimenting with utopic performatives, paying trans women (!), and planting a seed that can flourish into a nationally-touring show.
Annie Danger, the facilitator of this project, has a long and committed history to transformative (no pun intended...much) performance that doesn't lose a single ounce of fun and humor for all its earnesty. She has brought the world multiple full-length shows, including It's That Easy! With Terry VanWeen!, a motivational seminar for the revolution, and The Great Church of the Holy Fuck, a queer spiritual service about the power and healing in deeply queer sex and bodylove.


Other Ways You Can Help

Ooh! I don't have a ton of money either. If you don't have $5, $10, or $1000 for this campaign, no problem! Please:


Pass the word on! Tell your friends! Spread this campaign ALL OVER Facebutt, Twitter, and the rest of the internets!
If you're in the Bay Area this July, just come and see it!
If you're in the Bay Area this June, help us build sets and flyer!
Love trans women!

story:
Short Summary

An eclectic group of artists and engineers from the San Francisco Bay Area is developing new structures and ideas in a collaboration of art and science. We are building a Flower!

When we started this project, we didn't know exactly what we were building. We wanted to create an interactive work of Public Art that would challenge our minds, thrill and inspire people. We imagined something made of sensors, lights, sound and movement that would dance with it's audience. A wise friend advised us that our design should actually be something, not just some components or cool ideas, but a thing, like a flower. That is how the idea for the Desert Flower Artcar was born.

Experts of algebraic topology, software optimization, mechanical engineering, artists and musicians put their heads together and came up with a working model. Friends of all disciplines have collaborated and contributed to put the Desert Flower Artcar on the road and to make this a unique uplifting art experience. The Flower will debut at Burningman 2013, driving 5 MPH across the desert, carrying friends and strangers to create a spectacular experience. We are excited to share this work of art with the Public and look forward to showing it at Burningman as well as other events in the Bay Area for years to come.

The Desert Flower Artcar is large at 50 feet across and powered by a 7.3L Turbo Diesel Engine. Over 100 controllable sections of glow wire and spotlights turn on and off in response to your movement as you interact with 50 different sensors embedded around the Flower. At the center is an elliptical geodesic dome where you can dance underneath or climb on top, lounge in our hammocks, or escape the sun. The 15 frequency elliptical dome is made of 160 lengths of 1in steel pipe. Large, colorful shade structures surround the dome to create the petals of the Flower.

Your support makes our project possible. Please join us for a Birthday Party for the Desert Flower Artcar on Saturday, August 3 in Berkeley, CA, or find us on the Playa!

Information about the Birthday Party https://www.facebook.com/events/289371091209223/

As the flower grows, the reason we build it becomes more clear: Building brings people together. And flowers make people happy :-)

What We Need & What You Get

We will need $8500 to pay for the raw materials and equipment to finish this project. Any additional funding will go towards securing a location to store the Flower after Burningman.

Because this is the first year we are building the Desert Flower Artcar, we need to buy all the raw materials starting from scratch. We already invested a significant amount of our own money to get the project started, but to complete this project we need your help!

The next big expenses are the circuit board for the light controller, a thousand feet of El-Wire, and the raw materials and tools to fabricate the structure that holds the dome to the truck.

Here's what we've invested in so far

  • Ford F450 Truck with 7.3L Diesel Engine
  • Steel pipe for elliptical dome in center of our 50 foot desert flower
  • Tools for bending, cutting, and drilling the pipes
  • Structural material and fabric for our 20 foot flower petals

Here's what we still need your help with

  • Heavy-duty steel structure to support the dome and petals - $4000 
  • Nylon, PVC, fabric and other decor to disguise and beautify the truck - $1000
  • A light controller with over 100 different controllable lights and 50 ranging sensors to detect and interact with pedestrians who approach the car - $2500
  • A generator to power the lights and the sound system - $1000

We are keeping the receipt for every expense since the beginning of this project, so we can show you how your money is being spent. If we exceed our funding goals, we will use the money for these additional expenses:

  • Sound system for the vehicle
  • Storage for the Flower after Burningman
  • Large water containers to keep on the truck

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford to contribute money, you can still help build the Flower!

  • Visit us in Berkeley on the weekends, see the Flower and lend your hand in its construction. We are building the Flower at the Firehouse Art Collective Adeline Studios, 3192 Adeline St in Berkeley.
  • Come celebrate the Flower Birthday Party on Saturday, August 3. More information here https://www.facebook.com/events/289371091209223/
  • Get the word out and help make some noise about our project!

story:
What’s Going On

Hello! We are Bobble Kitty Comics, a brand new online comic website where people can come to read stories for free. Team Bobble Kitty is a two woman show. Creative team Gina Trujillo and Sonya Gonzales do literally everything; from writing the scripts to drawing and coloring the pages to building the website to running the social media pages. Because it’s only the two of us doing all of this, we need your help!

Team Bobble Kitty needs to get to Albuquerque Comic Expo in June. This has been our year-long mission to attend the Expo’s Artist’s Alley, but a life-long dream to create comics. It won’t happen without your support. This campaign is about getting to Albuquerque Comic Expo so we can give Bobble Kitty Comics a strong launch into the world, to talk with people about our projects face-to-face, to help generate interest in the online stories and start gathering readers for the long haul.


What We Need & What You Get

Our Expenses
We need to raise $1,450 to get to Albuquerque Comic Expo. We wiggled and squirmed and cut corners as much as we could to get that number.  To summarize, the money will be used for:
- Gas (it’s nearly 100 miles from home)
- The hotel room for the weekend
- Food and supplies for the weekend
- Our table and entry fee

The above list already accounts for literally half of what we need to raise. The rest goes to:
- Products to sell at the Expo
     - prints
     - posters
     - postcards
     - button pin sets
- Small expenses that add up
     - business cards
     - promo bookmarks
     - totes to carry it all
     - IndieGoGo/PayPal/Credit Card fees

Your Perks!
So what do you get for helping us raise this money?  We’re glad you asked! We’ve put together some perk packages for everyone, including:
-    Digital wallpapers packs for your desktop
-    Personalized Limericks
-    Button Pin Sets – Choose from My Little Pony or Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles!
-    Postcards (including TMNT designs and one special bonus card of Gina’s original work, “Apology.”)
-    Commissioned Artwork
-    Commissioned Comic Pages
-    Character Cameos in our online comic

Limericks writen by Sonya Gonzales!

 

All button pins measure 1&1/4 inch across.

All button pins measure 1&1/4 inch across.


If We Don’t Raise the Money
If we don’t reach our projected end goal, it’s going to be very hard to get to Albuquerque Comic Expo. Don’t think for a second that we’re gonna give up on this dream if we don’t reach our end goal. But borrowing money from people always sucks, and we don’t want to suck.

Plus if we don’t raise our goal amount, Gina will probably cry. In a strong, manly way. While wearing her 10th Doctor cosplay. And no one wants to see that. Seriously.


Why We’re Doing This

Comics are unlike any other form of storytelling in the world. For Bobble Kitty’s artist, Gina Trujillo, this format has always been a favored one. Like many, they were a lot more than just silly stories; they helped her through the hard times and the characters showed her how real life could be, if you make it so. Bobble Kitty Comics is a way to give back to the world, to join in with the voices of other storytellers and reach out to people who need a good story to help them through life now and again.


Other Ways You Can Help

Let people know! Share the campaign, Tweet about it, Facebook it, Google+, good ol’ email or carrier pigeon! Just let someone know about this campaign who might be interested in what we’re doing and what they can score from contributing.

Seriously, don’t forget to share. We love sharing. ;)

story:
The L is for Liberation Radicalphabet poster

The L is for Liberation Collective is a group of five Chicago-based friends, artists, and activists — Leora Abelson, Liz Cook, Lee Jacobs Riggs, Erin Moore, and Jeannette Perkal — responsible for organizing and curating the Radicalphabet poster. The project started over a year ago, while brainstorming gift ideas for a friend’s new baby. We wanted to give something that would reflect the social justice politics of the family and their community. But we realized there weren’t too many radical baby gifts out there, and so, together we birthed the idea for the Radicalphabet.

This project grew up around kitchen tables and in back-yards, on road trips and at living room dance parties. We chose 26 social justice concepts that represent diverse identities and movements, and then reached out to artists across the country to illustrate the letters. We are so excited that Katie Rains, Benjamin Stabler, Liz Wuerffel, Beth Gutelius, Ellery Russian, Mat Defiler, Sandie Stravis, Zoe Cohen, Julio Salgado, Joanna Schuman, Ruby Thorkelson, Alynn Guerra, Elisa Armea, Malic Amalya, Justin Alves, Jenna Peters-Golden, Chris Campe, Raquel Rodriguez, Andrea Larson, Ariel (El) Springfield, Laura Szumowski, Fabian Vasquez, and Kd Diamond signed on to contribute their artistic talents! Check out radicalphabet.org to get a full size glimpse at their amazing contributions. Now we’re in the final stages of making a fabulous poster that truly is a collective vision of liberation.

The L is for Liberation poster isn’t only about making a gift for a friend. Our hope is that educators, parents, caregivers, and other grown ups can use the Radicalphabet as a springboard for conversations with little ones about ideas of community, resistance, power, and difference. We want to offer the Radicalphabet as a teaching tool to orient young people toward social justice.

 

How you can help make it happen (and get cool stuff along the way)

This is where you come in! We hope to raise $2,950 to cover the cost of printing and shipping the poster. In addition to making it accessible to individuals, we want the poster to reach grassroots organizations and communities. We also want to send a free copy to each contributing artist. Plus, we want to honor the values represented on the poster by printing it through Salsedo Press, a local shop that uses eco-friendly methods and fair labor practices.  

With donation levels starting at $1, any amount you can give helps bring us closer to making this collective project a reality. And by contributing to the campaign, you will receive thank you gifts such as your very own copy of the Radicalphabet poster, fun swag like buttons and patches, and other art by contributing artists.

 

PLUS...

You can help nurture the Radicalphabet by spreading the word to your community and social networks. Share our video, like our facebook page, and talk us up on the town. Your support will help us plant these 26 small seeds of liberation in our many communities.

story:
HOLD STEADFAST- Tattooing To Benefit Victims of Hurricane Sandy

On December 2,2012, a group of tattoo artists and shops from all over the country will be tattooing from 12pm-8pm to raise money for victims of Hurricane Sandy in an effort to try and rebuild what was lost.

Participating artists will be contributing 8.5x11 sheets of flash designs which will be distributed to everyone who participates in the event. The designs from these sheets will be provided for you to choose from at every participating shop. Most designs are one-of-a-kind, and have been created by each artist to commemorate this day in which we all came together for one common cause.

All money earned will be donated the American Red Cross to help rebuild devestated communities and businesses.

What We Need & What You Get:

Here's how it will all go down:

  • From 12-8pm on this day, special tattoo flash sheets, designed by artists from all parts of the country, will be provided at participating tattoo shops for you to choose from to have tattooed.
  • Tattoos are going to be between $50 and $75 ( a $100-$200 value). More recently, a lot of the artists have drawn larger tattoos for the benefit. The larger choices of tattoo designs (valued at approx. $400) will be offered at half price ($200!!!!)
  • Though we have set a goal of raising $2500, we have lofty dreams of exceeding that goal, WITH YOUR HELP, of course!!  Should we not reach our goal, it matters not. Those of us who experienced the devestation here, or know and love someone who has, know that every little bit counts. Every last cent can help a family or small business in need. No good deed will go unnoticed or unappreciated. We, along with the American Red Cross, will feel blessed with whatever we do make.

Our Impact:

Want to know how the difference our contribution will make?

The effects of Hurricane Sandy were severe, particularly in New Jersey, New York City, its suburbs, and Long Island. Sandy's impacts included the flooding of the NYC subway system, many suburban communities, and all road tunnels entering Manhattan. Numerous homes and businesses were destroyed by fire, including over 100 homes in Queens alone. Large parts of the city and surrounding areas lost electricity for several days, some even went weeks. Large hospitals were closed and evacuated. At least 53 people died in New York as a result of the storm. Economic losses across New York were estimated to be at least $18 billion. Life in the tri-state area is just now returning to normal for some inhabitants, nearly a month after the fact. The American Red Cross has stopped at nothing to provide warmth, clothing, food, shelter, healthcare, love, and support for all those effected. We would be nowhere without their assistance in this time of need, and feel that sharing our art and trade with the world, in an effort to give back, is the best way to show our gratitude for their help.

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Some of you cannot make it on this day, some of you do not have the financial capability to contribute, some people are lovers of tattoos, and lovers of helping a good cause- but tattoos are just not for them. Rest assured there are ways you can be a part of this wonderful cause:

We are all involved in social media connections these days!! Share this event with your circle of friends and family! Ask THOSE folks to share this cause, and get the word out about what we are putting together. Indiegogo share tools are provided to make it one-click easy to let people know about our fundraiser! The ways any ounce of your time, attention, and help might not be seen initially, but it will be felt around the country in this great time of togetherness.

story:
Monmouth Arts has created ART HELPS  to work with local artists to help the community affected by Hurricane Sandy.

Art is great for restoring & rebuilding spirits 
When bad things happen to whole communities, it feels like everywhere you turn is just more misery and need. If you look a little harder though, you'll also see resilience and hope rising in the background. At Monmouth Arts, we think the arts are a powerful force when it comes to community building.

Why support ART HELPS?
Art impacts all members of a society; it inspires, connects, educates, heals, motivates, entertains and gives us a way to express our values, build bridges between cultures, and bring us together regardless of ethnicity, religion, or age. A small gift of the arts goes a long way towards getting back to the good stuff again--which is where we all want to be. Our communities need the arts!

How does ART HELPS work?
Art Helps will put local visual and performing artists to work offering presentations, performances and workshops to the communities affected by Hurricane Sandy. 

Some examples include:

  • Concerts at shelters
  • Art Activities for displaced families.
  • Tickets to local venues.
  • Touring theatre presentations at schools affected by the hurricane.
  • Mobile art workshops 

It's also good for artists! ART HELPS will:

  • Provide a listing of resources to connect artists with sources of funding and support
  • Connect need to sources of materials, supplies, and equipment
  • Provide funds to replace lost supplies

Let's not forget local arts organizations... ART HELPS will provide:

  • Consultation/assistance for arts organizations on a case by case basis
  • Connections to resources for arts organization to apply for outside funding... which will help them quickly get back on their feet.

Monmouth Arts Art Helps will focus on the needs of those affected by Hurricane Sandy in Monmouth County New Jersey. We need your support in order to support the arts in this area that has been so devastated by the hurricane. Please get the word out to the art lovers in your life. It can't fix everything, but we know ART HELPS! Thank you :)

About Monmouth Arts
At Monmouth Arts, our mission is simple: we enrich the community by inspiring and fostering the arts. We achieve this through arts education, collaboration, special events, grants, and more. In addition to supporting artists and art groups through our programs and services, we bring more than 2,500 high-quality, inexpensive or free concerts, films, dance and theater productions, musicals, creative writing programs, art exhibitions, and arts education programs to over 700,000 children and adults throughout the region each year.

As the official county arts agency, it’s our goal to perpetuate a vibrant arts community that truly enhances the quality of life in MonmouthCounty. Whether you’re an artist or a member of the audience, you’re sure to benefit from what MCAC has to offer. We hope that you’ll even consider supporting us to help keep our area’s many artistic endeavors alive and well.

Our programs are made possible through funding from the Monmouth County Board of Chosen Freeholders, through the County Historical Commission, and the New Jersey State Council on the Arts/ Department of State, a partner agency of the National Endowment of the Arts.

Contact us:

www.monmoutharts.org

newmedia@monmoutharts.org

732-212-1890 ext 5
story_txt:
Monmouth Arts has created ART HELPS  to work with local artists to help the community affected by Hurricane Sandy.
Art is great for restoring & rebuilding spirits When bad things happen to whole communities, it feels like everywhere you turn is just more misery and need. If you look a little harder though, you'll also see resilience and hope rising in the background. At Monmouth Arts, we think the arts are a powerful force when it comes to community building.
Why support ART HELPS? Art impacts all members of a society; it inspires, connects, educates, heals, motivates, entertains and gives us a way to express our values, build bridges between cultures, and bring us together regardless of ethnicity, religion, or age. A small gift of the arts goes a long way towards getting back to the good stuff again--which is where we all want to be. Our communities need the arts!
How does ART HELPS work?Art Helps will put local visual and performing artists to work offering presentations, performances and workshops to the communities affected by Hurricane Sandy. 
Some examples include:

Concerts at shelters
Art Activities for displaced families.
Tickets to local venues.
Touring theatre presentations at schools affected by the hurricane.
Mobile art workshops 
It's also good for artists! ART HELPS will:

Provide a listing of resources to connect artists with sources of funding and support
Connect need to sources of materials, supplies, and equipment
Provide funds to replace lost supplies
Let's not forget local arts organizations... ART HELPS will provide:

Consultation/assistance for arts organizations on a case by case basis
Connections to resources for arts organization to apply for outside funding... which will help them quickly get back on their feet.
Monmouth Arts Art Helps will focus on the needs of those affected by Hurricane Sandy in Monmouth County New Jersey. We need your support in order to support the arts in this area that has been so devastated by the hurricane. Please get the word out to the art lovers in your life. It can't fix everything, but we know ART HELPS! Thank you :)

story:
WHO WE ARE

No, we don’t sell antiques at The Geezer Gallery!  Maybe WE are “antiques”, but we embrace life and we love art. The Geezer Gallery is a “whole new old”, where we look at aging as a natural part of the human life course. We geezers take advantage of the wisdom and experience we’ve accumulated through years well lived. Growing old is not something to be disdained – we can live life to the fullest! Join us as we transform perceptions about old into something new.

At The Geezer Gallery, we display beautiful master-level art, and ALL of it is created by artists who are age 60 and above! We continue to have purpose in our lives because people are experiencing our art – and buying it. We artists have not packed away our palettes. We are continuing to be or just now becoming known in the community. We feel good knowing that the sale of our art is helping us continue to earn a living, but THAT’S not all. Sales of our art also help support art programs in senior communities, giving other seniors the opportunity to explore creative artistic expression that fosters personal creativity and enhances social connections. But THAT’S not all. It also helps support art therapy programs as a counseling tool to give seniors who need help a voice through artistic expression.

 

FUNDS NEEDED

Our campaign shows you who benefits and how. This is very important to those of us who are passionate about changing the perceptions of aging. Our campaign seeks to raise $15,000 to help support the art therapy programs. We artists are proud to be helping achieve this goal!

We hope you can hit the donate button TODAY so that, whatever your age, you can help us help other seniors. If you’re not a senior, think of it as an insurance policy for your future when you’re a senior, dispelling that myth that seniors have no value. This is important to all of us because ultimately it will show that seniors are a vital part of our society.

You can also help us get the word out by telling others about The Geezer Gallery and how you’re helping.  Share the stories you see on our video. We seniors can prove that it works. Tell others to visit the site and donate too.

RELATED NEWS ARTICLES:

Oregon ArtBeat

http://www.opb.org/programs/artbeat/segments/view/999

 

Oregon Live

http://www.oregonlive.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2012/02/geezer_gallery_celebrates_port.html

story:
Hello,

My name is Valentina, I am a young and dedicated digital artist who is passionate about my work. I spend most of my time painting and drawing, despite all the challenges I face in life such as recently discovered arthritis. However, aside of my own passion the feedback coming from people is what motivates me to go forward. I've been trying to expose the public to my work for a few years now and it's been going quite well- my facebook  page is currently at +1700 likes from people around the world. I am planning to get into illustration field so I can contribute to video games and other artistic fields. I would very much like to show more people what I am capable of and display my art in a downtown gallery , but I am limited financially- I pay for my college tuition and other needs by myself and it does not leave me with much to spare towards showing my work.

I am hoping to raise enough money before my 21st birthday on April 19th to rent space in the gallery for late spring and print a few more of my paintings on bigger canvases for display. It isn't cheap but offers good exposure, which would allow me to find solid ground for my future as an artist. It would be a big step for me and only a beginning of a long and exciting journey. I am ambitious and hardworking- I know I can and will go far as an artist, but it's the financial side that needs to be invested in at this point. However, if I do not reach my financial goal, I am planning to print art books of my work and distribute them to the galleries- it would be a smaller scale investment but when you have a dream even a small step towards it counts.

I have earned an award from Humber college for Art competition 2012 and I am doing it again next week. For the category I was competing in , I and two other winners have been selected from over 500 submissions, which really showed me that I am heading in the right direction artistically and skill-wise.
I am hoping to win again this year, so please wish me luck!

Even though I can't offer much back at this moment aside of karma points, I can offer some of the perks in return, please look at them.

First 5 contributors will get a signed print of one of my works yours to choose)  upon completion of my campaign, just don't forget to e-mail me right away at:
pestilencegraphics@gmail.com

If the goal is reached I will update all of you on the date the gallery will feature my work and where it is located, so if you are nearby you can pop by and say hello. I will also post pictures for those who can't make it.

If you are unable to help me out but like my work, please share this link and visit my facebook page!

Thank you for your time,

Val

story:
Volunteer Group of Artistic Mindsets (VOGRAM) is a non-governmental organization that brings together young activists interested in improving their local communities and global connectivity with positive trends through cultural exchange and activism. Therefore, particularly we support activities and education related to culture, art and creative work, and the values of civil society with a focus on human rights and sustainable development. We organize professional meetings, youth exchanges, seminars, counseling and other forms of education, as well as cultural events, festivals, debates and open discussions. We gather volunteers, who wish to participate in our activities, inform them about the possibilities of local communities and motivate them to become active members of society.

The aim of the project is to promote local and regional, young, unknown artists, musicians and bands, to popularize hip hop culture and educate the public about the scale of cultural impact rap music has, taking criticizing point of view to social problems in modern society.

The project is based on a thorough organization and elaborate work, supplemented by experience of the festival "HIP-HOP URA" organized in 2006, 2007, and 2008, financially supported by Forum Syd and Youth Center in Novi Sad. 

This is the 4th time the festival will be organized, but this time it will be extended to activities other than music performance. The festival will include following activities:

  • Music section includes appearance of well known and unknown rap artists from the region
  • More than 20 mostly less-known individuals and groups, selected according to the quality and potential of affirmation
  • Graffiti competition - large format canvases
  • Dancing competition– All Style teams
  • Competition in extreme skateboarding
  • Stands for NGO’s
  • Open discussion on the topic "Hip-hop between art and life"
  • Dance workshops with teachers from Urban Dance Crew Hungary in collaboration with the dance association Groove

The festival will be held at an attractive location - Limanski Park in Novi Sad. Dancing competition, graffiti drawing and skateboarding will be held during the day and will be open to the public, while the music program and the finals in the all styles dance competition will be held in the evening in the club "Factory” along with the musical part of the festival, and it will be available with a ticket.

Our hope is that this project with a lot of work, love and real friends create a traditional event that will grow into a cultural institution of high traffic and high quality.

"Hip Hop URA" is the only festival of its kind in the country. It comes as a response to the request of a large number of young people who do not have adequate opportunities to enjoy and create within their subculture.

The target group consists of young people from 14 to 30, who are loyal to the hip-hop subculture and ideology that are willing to travel throughout the country and the region to attend these events. They see festivals and gatherings with people who think alike as an extended family event and they experience freeing of the mind, it is a place where they find understanding and support. It is also a way of finding understanding between conflict nations in the Balkans, by building a sense of togetherness and tolerance by using art as a medium of communication. 

In Novi Sad there are about 80,000 young people who live here and study. We are looking forward to host at least 1000 people in the course of daily activities, and an additional 450 who will attend the music part of the festival.

We need your support to make Hip Hop URA festival happen this year, and we believe that together we can reach this goal. Your contribution will help us host and accommodate artists from the Balkan region, and make them feel comfortable and creative within the festival surroundings. It will help us acquire all the necessary props for artists and competitors as well as to get appropriate awards for the best performers.

This year the project is supported by the city of Novi Sad with 1300EUR but additional finances are necessary. The total cost of the project is 3200EUR (4235USD).

  

 

We have a lot of awesome perks to thank you for your contribution to the project, depending on your donation! 

What you can get: 

HOW TO CHOOSE YOUR PERKS??? (Only applicable to perks that are marked with a code):

If your choice includes a wallpaper, poster, CD or a t-shirt, you can select below:

  • Choose the cagetory of your perk from the preview above
  • Check the list below where perks have codes, see the code with the perk of your choice  
  • After selecting your perk, type the code(s), and then write your FULL ADDRESS
  • If you don't include the codes of your perks, contact us VIA email.

If you have any questions, take a look at the FAQ or contact us directly at hiphopura@vogram-serbia.com 

LARGER PREVIEW OF PERKS (with codes):

  • Personal Thank you on our website and Facebook page (code: Y1)

 

  • Wallpaper of the festival for your computer

  

                                W1                                                                              W2

  • Poster signed by the artists of the festival

                                   P1

                                  P2

  • Signed CD of one artist of the festival

                              C1

  • T-shirt of the festival

                                                               T1

 

                      

                                        T2

 

  • Video of the festival with a personal Thank you in it (code: V1)

 

  • Artwork done by one of our artists (example below)

  • Personal portrait drawn by one artist of the festival according to the picture of your choice

  • The WINNING CANVAS painted by the winning artist of the competition! (only 1 available)

 

Just help spread the good word! If you don't wish to make a donation directly, you can help us by sharing this page and the website of the festival on your web pages and social networks. Or if you might know someone who would be willing to help the project, connect us! Thank you! 

  • Why do we need more money this year to organize the festival?

This year, we decided to extend the festival, adding competitions in dance, skateboarding and graffiti drawing. We want to offer a space to any kind of hip hop artists to express themselves and become recognized artists.  Also this year, the festival is only supported by the city of Novi Sad. This is why we need your help to make it happen!

  • If we raise more money than we need, what will we do with it?

First, we will improve the festival organization by renting better material and props for it (sound system, stage, lights …). Then, we will have the possibility to buy more spray cans with diversified colors for the graffiti competition. We will also have the great opportunity to make the entire festival free, including the evening competitions. Finally, we will spend more money to take pictures, record the festival, and create the video.

  • How will we know which perks you want for the “Pick up what you want” category? Or your size for the T-shirts?

Don’t worry, we will contact you to arrange everything! All sizes and models available (XS – XXXL)

  • You have more questions?

Don’t hesitate to contact us! hiphopura@vogram-serbia.com

story:
English (start)   /   Español (más abajo)   /   Deutsch (ganz unten)  /   about me

(PS upfront: My promise, I will go back to the border in late November and continue the project with your contribution, even if I don't reach the financial goal. Still every dolllar counts :-)

 

My name is  STEFAN FALKE, I am a German born photographer in Brooklyn, New York. 

LA FRONTERA: Artists along the US Mexican Border

is my newest project. I started to photograph artists in Tijuana in 2008 because I wanted to show that there is more to the border region than bad news. My first series of photographs inspired me to go further.

I decided to visit and portray artists along the entire 2000 miles long US-Mexican border because the media reports from the border regions are still almost entirely focusing on violent crime.

I want to tell another story.

I am hoping that my LA FRONTERA project will help to put a spotlight on the vibrant cultural life along the border that most people in the US and other countries know very little about.

I went back to Baja California earlier this year to visit and photograph more artists along the border in Tijuana, Tecate and Mexicali.

At the same time I was invited to show my work at La Casa Del Tunel: Art Center in Tijuana, where I also held a 4 day workshop for local photographers.

The exhibition was very well received and publicized in the press. As a result, I became connected to more artists and art institutions. The German embassy in Mexico City published an interview with me about the exhibition and my work at the border (in Spanish).

Now I am planning a 3 months trip to visit again Tijuana, Tecate, Mexicali, Nogales, Juarez, Nuevo Laredo, Reynosa, Matamoros and smaller towns along the border to meet artists in their homes and studios. I also want to explore San Diego, El Paso and Brownsville as well as other towns on the US side where many artists live and work.

 

 

I am hoping to go back to the border in early November after working on magazine assignments about the Presidential Elections in the US. The length of my trip along the border ultimately depends on how much money I will have. I am planning for 3 month because of the distances and my experience with the earier visits. It often takes a lot of time to arrange meetings and coordinate travel and visits. I will also photograph landscape and the border fence in many locations.

Luckily the nature of this project allows for separate trips to different regions in case I need to come back to New York to search for more financial support.

My long-term goal is to produce a book about the project similar in scope to my 215-page photo book about a stilt walking school in Trinidad. It was published under the title Moko Jumbies: The Dancing Spirits of Trinidad by Pointed Leaf Press in New York. Photographs from the book were exhibited at VISA POUR L'IMAGE, the famous photojournalism festival in Perpignan/France and the story was published in magazines all over the world. (tear sheets)

(The production of a final book is NOT part of this fundraising effort. This campaign is needed to cover the costs to produce the photographs along the border that will eventually become a book. But I will design a spezial edition with images from LA FRONTERA on blurb.com as a gift for my supporters)

 

I already created a blog which will include photos and information about every artist who is part of the project. I will further improve the site when I return from the next trip. 

Please also visit and like the project's facebook page !!

Interviews and stories will be written by Claudia Steinberg, an internationally published journalist based in New York City. She has participated in previous trips and will join me at different locations during my travels. In addition I will ask poets, novelists and journalists from the various regions along the border to contribute texts about their experiences of life at La Frontera. 

However, at this stage my most urgent concern is to be able to go back and continue to photograph artists along the border.

I financed the first trips myself, but now I need your help to continue this project.

Even though I have been awarded a grant (8,000 Euro) from a German foundation (Stiftung Kulturwerk der VG BILD-KUNST) I still need more funds for the 3 month trip: 90 days car rental - up to 70 $ per day in Mexico / car insurance in mexico / gas - I expect to drive at least 5000 miles / up to 90 motel nights / add. equipment: Nikon D 800 for video interviews (what I really want: the more expensive Nikon D4) /  microphone for video etc / add. digital storage / min. 2 return flights NY - border /communication / local assistants /  ...)

I will also continue to write proposals for grants from foundations because I can see myself spending much more time working on this project than the initial 3 month. Grant writing and receiving is a slow process. This fundraising campaign will hopefully allow me to continue with the work in November 2012.

Whatever you can contribute to this project will be very much appreciated. And if you just post this video on your facebook page or tell others about it … that would be fantastic !! :-)

www.stefanfalke.com

..........................................................................................................................................

"This is one of the most incredible projects I have seen to date on this issue."

Mary Stephens, Producing Director
Performance in the Borderlands - Arizona State University
 
..........................................................................................................................................
 

 

 

En Español:

 

Hola,

mi nombre es Stefan FALKE, soy fotógrafo de origen alemán y vivo en Brooklyn, Nueva York.

Mi nuevo proyecto se llama 

LA FRONTERA: Artistas a lo largo de la frontera entre Mexico y EE.UU.

Comencé a fotografiar a artistas en Tijuana en 2008 porque quería mostrar que hay más en la frontera que solo malas noticias. Mi primera serie de imágenes me inspiró a ir más allá.

Decidí a visitar y retratar a artistas en todas las 2000 millas a lo largo de la frontera  de México con Estados Unidos, ya que los informes de los medios de las regiones fronterizas son todavía casi totalmente centrados en la delincuencia violenta.

Quiero contarles una historia diferente.

Espero que mi proyecto LA FRONTERA pondrá el foco en la vida cultural vibrante a lo largo de la frontera de la que la mayoría de las personas en los EE.UU. y en otros países saben muy poco.

Volví a la frontera en Baja California a principios de este año para visitar y fotografiar a más artistas en Tijuana,Tecate y Mexicali.


Al mismo tiempo, me invitaron a exponer mi trabajo en La Casa Del Tunel: Art Center en Tijuana, donde también realizé un taller de cuatro días para fotógrafos locales.

La exposición fue muy bien recibida y publicada en la prensa. Como resultado, me conecté a aun más artistas e instituciones artísticas. La embajada alemana en la Ciudad de México publicó una entrevista conmigo acerca de la exposición y mi trabajo en la frontera (en español).

Me sentí cada vez más animado a continuar mi trabajo de LA FRONTERA.

Ahora estoy planeando un viaje de 3 meses para visitar a Tijuana, Tecate, Mexicali, Nogales, Ciudad Juárez, NuevoLaredo, Reynosa, Matamoros y ciudades más pequeñas a lo largo de la frontera para conocer a los artistas en sus casas y sua talleres. También quiero explorar a San Diego, El Paso y Brownsville, así como otras ciudades del lado de EE.UU., donde muchos artistas viven y trabajan.



Espero poder volver a la frontera a principios de noviembre después de finalizar algunos  encargos de revistas sobre las elecciones presidenciales en EE.UU.. En última instancia, la duración de mi viaje a lo largo de la frontera depende de la cantidad de dinero que puedo juntar. Estoy planeando para un viaje de 3 meses debido a las distancias que hay que recorrer y a base de mis experiencias en visitas anteriores. Se necesita mucho tiempo para encontrar a los artistas y organizar citas con los artistas.

Por suerte, la naturaleza de este proyecto permite tener varios viajes a diferentes regiones en el caso que tengo que volver a Nueva York en busqueda de apoyos financieros adicionales.

Mi meta a largo plazo es producir un libro sobre el proyecto similar en volume a mi libro de fotos de 215 páginas sobre la escuela de andar en zancos en Trinidad. Se publicó bajo el título MOKO JUMBIES: Los espíritus danzantes de Trinidad por la editorial Pointed Leaf Press en Nueva York. Fotografías de este libro se exhibieron en VISA POUR L’IMAGE, el famoso festival de fotoperiodismo en Perpignan/Francia y la historia se public en revistas de todo el mundo (Ver hojas individuales de papel).

(La producción de un libro definitivo no es parte de este esfuerzo de recaudación de fondos. Esta campaña es necesaria para cubrir los costos de producción de las fotografías a lo largo de la frontera que, con el tiempo, se convertirán en libro. Pero voy a diseñar una edición especial con imágenes de LA FRONTERA  en blurb.com como un regalo para mis aportadores).

Ya he creado un blog que incluirá fotos e información sobre cada artista que participa en el proyecto. Incluso mejoraré aun más la página web cuando regreso de mi siguiente viaje.

Por favor, también visite y gusta la página facebook del proyecto!



Las entrevistas y las historias estarán escritas por Claudia Steinberg, una periodista publicada a nivel internacional con sede en Nueva York. Ha participado en viajes anteriores y se juntaráconmigo en diferentes lugares durante mis viajes. Además voy a pedir a poetas, novelistas y periodistas de las diversas regiones a lo largo de la frontera que contribuyeran textos sobre sus experiencias vitales en La Frontera.

Sin embargo, en este momento mi preocupación más urgente es poder volver y continuar a fotografiar artistas a lo largo de la frontera.

Los primeros viajes he pagado e mi propio bolsillo, sin embargo,  ahora necesito la ayuda de vosotros para continuar con este proyecto.

A pesar de que me han concedido una beca (8.000 euros) de una fundación alemana (Stiftung Kulturwerk der VG Bild-Kunst), me faltan aun más fondos para los tres meses,  como por ejemplo gastos de viaje, equipo adicional, varios seguros así como asistentes locales.

Lo qué necesito para 3 mes:

90 días de alquiler de coch - hasta 70 $ por día en México / seguro de automóvil en México / gasolina – Asumo que voy a recorrer por lo menos unas 5000 millas / 90 noches de motel /Equipo addicional: Nikon D 800 para vídeo (mejor aún: la D4) / micrófono etc / almacenamiento digital addicional/ 2 vuelos de regreso NY - frontera / asistencia local / comunicación (los costes de itinerancia/roaming) / ...)

Lo que sea que  usted pueda contribuir a este proyecto será muy apreciado. E incluso si somplemente publica este video en su página de facebook o le dice a otros acerca del proyecto ... eso sería fantástico! :-)

www.stefanfalke.com

Mary Stephens, Producing Director

Performance in the Borderlands - Arizona State University
