Deutsch:

 

Hallo,

mein Name ist Stefan Falke, ein deutscher Fotograf in Brooklyn, New York.

 Mein neuestes Projekt heißt

LA FRONTERA: Künstler entlang der US - mexikanischen Grenze

Ich fing 2008 an Künstler in Tijuana zu fotografieren, weil ich zeigen wollte, dass es nicht nur schlechte Nachrichten von der Grenze zu berichten gab. Meine erste Serie von Bildern inspirierte mich dazu, weiter zu gehen.

 Ich entschied mich Künstler entlang der gesamten 2000 Meilen langen US-mexikanischen Grenze zu besuchen und zu fotografieren, weil die internationalen Medien aus den Grenzregionen fast immer nur mit dem Schwerpunkt Gewaltverbrechen berichten. 

Ich möchte eine andere Geschichte zu erzählen.

 Ich hoffe mein LA FRONTERA Projekt kann dabei helfen ein Schlaglicht auf das lebendige kulturelle Leben entlang der Grenze zu werfen. Ein Leben von dem die meisten Menschen in den USA und anderen Ländern sehr wenig wissen.

 

 

 

Zu Beginn dieses Jahres war ich wieder in Baja California um weitere Künstler in Tijuana, Tecate und Mexicali zu fotografieren.

 Zur gleichen Zeit wurde ich eingeladen, meine Arbeit im La Casa Del Tunel zeigen: Art Center in Tijuana zu zeigen, wo ich auch einen 4-tägigen Workshop für lokale Fotografen unterrichtete. 

Die Ausstellung wurde sehr gut angenommen und in der mexikanischen Presse veröffentlicht. Dadurch lernte ich weitere Künstler und Kunstinstitutionen kennen. Die deutsche Botschaft in Mexico City veröffentlichte dazu ein Interview mit mir über die Ausstellung und meine Arbeit an der Grenze (in Spanisch).

Jetzt plane ich eine 3 monatige Reise nach Tijuana, Tecate, Mexicali, Nogales, Juarez, Nuevo Laredo, Reynosa, Matamoros und zu kleineren Städten entlang der Grenze um Künstler in ihren Häusern und Studios zu besuchen. Ich möchte auch San Diego, El Paso und Brownsville sowie andere Städte auf der US-Seite, wo viele Künstler leben und arbeiten, erkunden.

Ich hoffe gleich nach den Präsidentschaftswahlen in den USA mit meiner Arbiet fortfahren zu können. Die Länge der Reise entlang der Grenze hängt letztlich davon ab, wie viel Geld ich dafür haben werde. Wegen der grossen Entfernungen plane ich für 3 Monate. Auch braucht es nach den Erfahrungen meiner letzten Reise es oft viel Zeit, um Treffen mit Künstlern zu arrangieren und zu koordinieren. Auch Landschafts und Fotos vom Grenzzaun an verschiedenen Orten nimmt viel Zeit in Anspruch.

Zum Glück ermöglicht dieses Projekts separate Reisen in verschiedene Regionen, für den Fall das ich nach New York zurückkehren müsste um weitere finanzielle Unterstützung zu finden.

Mein langfristiges Ziel ist es ein Buch über das Projekt zu veröffentlichen, ähnlich in Grösse und Umfang meines 215-Seiten Fotobuches über ein Stelzenlauf Schule in Trinidad. Das Buch wurde von Pointed Leaf Press in New York unter dem Titel MOKO JUMBIES: The Dancing Spirits of Trinidad veröffentlicht. Fotografien aus dem Buch wurden auf dem Fotojournalismus-Festival Visa pour l'Image in Perpignan / Frankreich ausgestellt und die Bilder wurde in Magazinen auf der ganzen Welt veröffentlicht. (Siehe Auszüge)

(Die Herstellung eines endgültigen Buch ist nicht Teil dieser Spendenaktion. Diese Spendenkampagne ist nötig, um die Kosten zu decken, die Fotografien entlang der Grenze zu produzieren. Ich werde aber eine Sonder-Edition mit Bildern aus LA FRONTERA auf blurb.com als Geschenk für meine Unterstützer auflegen) 

 Ich habe bereits ein Blog online gestellt auf dem Fotos und Informationen über jeden Künstler, welcher Teil des Projekts ist, enthalten sein wird. Nach der nächsten Reise wird der Blog zu einer Webseite wachsen.

 Bitte besuchen Sie auch meine LA FRONTERA Facebook-Seite!

 

 

Claudia Steinberg, international tätige Journalistin in New York City, wird die interviews und Geschichten zu dem Projekt schreiben. Sie hat schon an vergangenen Reisen nach Tijuana teilgenommen und wird mich an verschiedenen Orten während meiner nächsten Reise besuchen. Darüber hinaus werde ich Dichter, Schriftsteller und Journalisten aus den verschiedenen Regionen entlang der Grenze bitten, Texte über ihre Erfahrungen mit dem Leben an der Grenze beizutragen.

Mein wichtigstes Anliegen ist momentan zurückzkehren zu können um weitere Künstlern entlang der Grenze zu besuchen und zu fotografieren.

Ich habe die ersten Reisen selbst finanziert, aber jetzt brauche ich Ihre Hilfe um dieses Projekt weiterzuführen.

Trotz einer bewilligten Förderung einer deutschen Stiftung (Stiftung Kulturwerk der VG BILD-KUNST, 8.000 Euro) brauche noch mehr Mittel um die 3-monatige Reise verwirklichen zu können.  90 Tage Mietwagen - bis zu 70 $ pro Tag in Mexiko / Kfz-Versicherung in Mexiko / Gas - ca 5000 Meilen Fahrt/ bis zu 90 Motel Nächte  / Zusätzliche Ausrüstung: Nikon D 800 für Video-Interviews (was ich wirklich wollen würde: die teurere Nikon D4) / Mikrofon für Video etc / hinzuzufügen. digitale Speicherung / min. 2 Hin-und Rückflüge NY - Grenze / local Assistenten / Kommunikation / ...)

Ich freue mich über jede Unterstützung. Und wenn Sie nur dieses Video auf Ihrer Facebook-Seite zeigen oder es einfach weitersagen ... das wäre schon fantastisch! :-) Vielen Dank !!

www.stefanfalke.com

 

"Dies ist eines der unglaublichsten Projekte, welches ich zu diesem Thema gesehen habe."

Mary Stephens, Producing Director

Performance in den Borderlands - Arizona State University
story_txt:
English (start)   /   Español (más abajo)   /   Deutsch (ganz unten)  /   about me
(PS upfront: My promise, I will go back to the border in late November and continue the project with your contribution, even if I don't reach the financial goal. Still every dolllar counts :-)
 
My name is  STEFAN FALKE, I am a German born photographer in Brooklyn, New York. 
LA FRONTERA: Artists along the US Mexican Border
is my newest project. I started to photograph artists in Tijuana in 2008 because I wanted to show that there is more to the border region than bad news. My first series of photographs inspired me to go further.
I decided to visit and portray artists along the entire 2000 miles long US-Mexican border because the media reports from the border regions are still almost entirely focusing on violent crime.
I want to tell another story.
I am hoping that my LA FRONTERA project will help to put a spotlight on the vibrant cultural life along the border that most people in the US and other countries know very little about.



I went back to Baja California earlier this year to visit and photograph more artists along the border in Tijuana, Tecate and Mexicali.
At the same time I was invited to show my work at La Casa Del Tunel: Art Center in Tijuana, where I also held a 4 day workshop for local photographers.
The exhibition was very well received and publicized in the press. As a result, I became connected to more artists and art institutions. The German embassy in Mexico City published an interview with me about the exhibition and my work at the border (in Spanish).
Now I am planning a 3 months trip to visit again Tijuana, Tecate, Mexicali, Nogales, Juarez, Nuevo Laredo, Reynosa, Matamoros and smaller towns along the border to meet artists in their homes and studios. I also want to explore San Diego, El Paso and Brownsville as well as other towns on the US side where many artists live and work.
 

 

I am hoping to go back to the border in early November after working on magazine assignments about the Presidential Elections in the US. The length of my trip along the border ultimately depends on how much money I will have. I am planning for 3 month because of the distances and my experience with the earier visits. It often takes a lot of time to arrange meetings and coordinate travel and visits. I will also photograph landscape and the border fence in many locations.
Luckily the nature of this project allows for separate trips to different regions in case I need to come back to New York to search for more financial support.
My long-term goal is to produce a book about the project similar in scope to my 215-page photo book about a stilt walking school in Trinidad. It was published under the title Moko Jumbies: The Dancing Spirits of Trinidad by Pointed Leaf Press in New York. Photographs from the book were exhibited at VISA POUR L'IMAGE, the famous photojournalism festival in Perpignan/France and the story was published in magazines all over the world. (tear sheets)
(The production of a final book is NOT part of this fundraising effort. This campaign is needed to cover the costs to produce the photographs along the border that will eventually become a book. But I will design a spezial edition with images from LA FRONTERA on blurb.com as a gift for my supporters)
 
I already created a blog which will include photos and information about every artist who is part of the project. I will further improve the site when I return from the next trip. 
Please also visit and like the project's facebook page !!
Interviews and stories will be written by Claudia Steinberg, an internationally published journalist based in New York City. She has participated in previous trips and will join me at different locations during my travels. In addition I will ask poets, novelists and journalists from the various regions along the border to contribute texts about their experiences of life at La Frontera. 
However, at this stage my most urgent concern is to be able to go back and continue to photograph artists along the border.
I financed the first trips myself, but now I need your help to continue this project.
Even though I have been awarded a grant (8,000 Euro) from a German foundation (Stiftung Kulturwerk der VG BILD-KUNST) I still need more funds for the 3 month trip: 90 days car rental - up to 70 $ per day in Mexico / car insurance in mexico / gas - I expect to drive at least 5000 miles / up to 90 motel nights / add. equipment: Nikon D 800 for video interviews (what I really want: the more expensive Nikon D4) /  microphone for video etc / add. digital storage / min. 2 return flights NY - border /communication / local assistants /  ...)
I will also continue to write proposals for grants from foundations because I can see myself spending much more time working on this project than the initial 3 month. Grant writing and receiving is a slow process. This fundraising campaign will hopefully allow me to continue with the work in November 2012.
Whatever you can contribute to this project will be very much appreciated. And if you just post this video on your facebook page or tell others about it … that would be fantastic !! :-)
www.stefanfalke.com

LA FRONTERA: Künstler entlang der US - mexikanischen Grenze

Die Länge der Reise entlang der Grenze hängt letztlich davon ab, wie viel Geld ich dafür haben werde. Wegen der grossen Entfernungen plane ich für 3 Monate. Auch braucht es nach den Erfahrungen meiner letzten Reise es oft viel Zeit, um Treffen mit Künstlern zu arrangieren und zu koordinieren. Auch Landschafts und Fotos vom Grenzzaun an verschiedenen Orten nimmt viel Zeit in Anspruch.
Zum Glück ermöglicht dieses Projekts separate Reisen in verschiedene Regionen, für den Fall das ich nach New York zurückkehren müsste um weitere finanzielle Unterstützung zu finden.
Mein langfristiges Ziel ist es ein Buch über das Projekt zu veröffentlichen, ähnlich in Grösse und Umfang meines 215-Seiten Fotobuches über ein Stelzenlauf Schule in Trinidad. Das Buch wurde von Pointed Leaf Press in New York unter dem Titel MOKO JUMBIES: The Dancing Spirits of Trinidad veröffentlicht. Fotografien aus dem Buch wurden auf dem Fotojournalismus-Festival Visa pour l'Image in Perpignan / Frankreich ausgestellt und die Bilder wurde in Magazinen auf der ganzen Welt veröffentlicht. (Siehe Auszüge)
(Die Herstellung eines endgültigen Buch ist nicht Teil dieser Spendenaktion. Diese Spendenkampagne ist nötig, um die Kosten zu decken, die Fotografien entlang der Grenze zu produzieren. Ich werde aber eine Sonder-Edition mit Bildern aus LA FRONTERA auf blurb.com als Geschenk für meine Unterstützer auflegen) 
 Ich habe bereits ein Blog online gestellt auf dem Fotos und Informationen über jeden Künstler, welcher Teil des Projekts ist, enthalten sein wird. Nach der nächsten Reise wird der Blog zu einer Webseite wachsen.
 Bitte besuchen Sie auch meine LA FRONTERA Facebook-Seite!
 

 
Claudia Steinberg, international tätige Journalistin in New York City, wird die interviews und Geschichten zu dem Projekt schreiben. Sie hat schon an vergangenen Reisen nach Tijuana teilgenommen und wird mich an verschiedenen Orten während meiner nächsten Reise besuchen. Darüber hinaus werde ich Dichter, Schriftsteller und Journalisten aus den verschiedenen Regionen entlang der Grenze bitten, Texte über ihre Erfahrungen mit dem Leben an der Grenze beizutragen.
Mein wichtigstes Anliegen ist momentan zurückzkehren zu können um weitere Künstlern entlang der Grenze zu besuchen und zu fotografieren.
Ich habe die ersten Reisen selbst finanziert, aber jetzt brauche ich Ihre Hilfe um dieses Projekt weiterzuführen.
Trotz einer bewilligten Förderung einer deutschen Stiftung (Stiftung Kulturwerk der VG BILD-KUNST, 8.000 Euro) brauche noch mehr Mittel um die 3-monatige Reise verwirklichen zu können.  90 Tage Mietwagen - bis zu 70 $ pro Tag in Mexiko / Kfz-Versicherung in Mexiko / Gas - ca 5000 Meilen Fahrt/ bis zu 90 Motel Nächte  / Zusätzliche Ausrüstung: Nikon D 800 für Video-Interviews (was ich wirklich wollen würde: die teurere Nikon D4) / Mikrofon für Video etc / hinzuzufügen. digitale Speicherung / min. 2 Hin-und Rückflüge NY - Grenze / local Assistenten / Kommunikation / ...)
Ich freue mich über jede Unterstützung. Und wenn Sie nur dieses Video auf Ihrer Facebook-Seite zeigen oder es einfach weitersagen ... das wäre schon fantastisch! :-) Vielen Dank !!
www.stefanfalke.com

 
"Dies ist eines der unglaublichsten Projekte, welches ich zu diesem Thema gesehen habe."
Mary Stephens, Producing Director
Performance in den Borderlands - Arizona State University

story:
MY STORY

Crafting for me is not only a passion but a way of life. I first started making jewelry for myself and I thought, "why not sell my ideas too?"

I opened my etsy store in January of 2011 and haven't looked back. I started with my polymer clay jewelry and branched out 6 months later with greeting cards. Now I'm looking to expand my store once again with buttons!

THE CAT COLLECTION

I have a mad love for cats. So I decided to make a collection of cats and their breeds. The humorous twist is the play on their breed names.

I have produced 3 of the 30+ breeds to show you what I'm looking to make. The Russian Blue is sporting an eye patch, an Ushanka (Russian hat), and red scarf. The British Longhair is a British gentleman wearing a tux and top hat and sporting a monocle. And the Scottish Fold is wearing a kilt, a Tam (Scottish hat) and orange 'stache and sideburns.

I plan on making all of the breeds into buttons and jewelry. I'm really excited to share them and I think they are a lot of fun!

WHAT THE PROJECT WILL FUND

What $300 of the project will fund is a 1" button machine (image shown below)

 

The $200 left will be for the button supplies. Each supply is sold seperately and I need the following:

The shell is the front of the button, the pin back is the pointy metal for your shirt or wherever you're putting the button, and the mylar is the shiny protective coat over the button.

 

THE REWARDS

- $1 or more you will receive a digital thank you card, made by me. It's a surprise but it's cat-themed!

- $5 or more you will receive all 3 buttons. The Russian Blue, the British Longhair and the Scottish Fold. All 3 buttons will be 1".

- $15 or more you choose 1 of the 3 rings below! The cats are all .5" and are fully adjustable. Each are made with polymer clay and acrylic paint. Don't want your cat as a ring? I can make it a magnet!

- $25 or more you choose 1 of 3 necklaces below! The pendant is 1" tall and is on an 18" ball chain necklace. Each necklace is made with polymer clay and acrylic paint. The whiskers are made with colored wires. The Scottish Fold has a pom on his hat and his kilt is made with ribbon. Don't want your cat as a necklace? I can make it a figurine!

- $50 or more you will receive all 3 buttons, all 3 rings AND 1 necklace.

- $75 or more you will receive all 3 buttons, all 3 rings AND all 3 necklaces!

 

CONCLUSION

If you couldn't tell, I'm a crafter. I live for the moment when I finish a project and see it come to life in my hands. I want to have fun with my work and share it with the world. And I hope in this project you can see that!

Thank you for checking out my cat collection, and please spread the word if you like it. Every dollar helps!

story:
What We Currently Do

ONiT! PR provides training and development opportunities coupled with booking management solutions and competitive media relation services to performance artists and creative educational practitioners.  We assist independents and SME’s with PR and marketing expertise for performance specific entertainment and supply performers to anyone who’ll pay for them!

 

 

 

What We Would Like To Do Next

We’ve discovered an exciting opportunity to develop the business via assistance from creative champions, CIDA (Cultural Industries Development Agency).  CIDA are offering a fantastic opportunity that could see ONiT! PR realise its vision, aims and objectives for 2013 and beyond; to continue to develop the performance careers of Artists, as well as offer affordable support. 

 

What We’re Asking You To Help Us With

ONiT! PR is aiming to raise £1,000, which will be used to fund our projects for the first quarter of 2013.  To make this possible, we need your support.

Between now and Friday 30th November, we’d love you to contribute £15 (or more) towards our campaign and help spread the word about what we’re trying to achieve.

 

 

 

 

We appreciate that there’s no such thing as something for nothing in this world, so we have some perks for you (see grey boxes to the right of your screen), ranging from thank you acknowledgements to a 4 week digital PR & Marketing campaign plus much more in between. 

These perks aren’t specific to Artists either; anyone who runs a business, wants to develop a personal brand or would benefit from taking a more strategic approach to life, can take advantage of these opportunities.

 

What Happens Next?

With your help, we reach our target and implement the changes from 3rd December!

In the event that we don’t reach our full target, whatever we do raise will still be invested into implementing the programme.  However, we believe that this is a more than achievable goal, and have faith in your ability to help us make this mission an accomplished one.

 

Thanks for taking the time to read our pitch; it means a lot to us.

 

 

Please copy and paste the URL to this page (http://www.indiegogo.com/HELP-ONiT-TO-SWINGiT), and post it to your Facebook page, Twitter timeline (our handle is @onitpr and the campaign hashtag is #ONiT2SWINGiT), blog, Blackberry Messenger status and any other platform that you'd be comfortable sharing it on.   

 

 

ONiT! PR - Passionate about Performance

story:
INFINITE ANSWERS

My name is Aaron Alviano and I am a visual artist that specializes in photography, painting and sculpture. I am originally from Guelph, Canada where I studied and received my Bachelors of Fine Art. Since then I have moved to the "big city" of Toronto, Canada and have put on several art shows through out southern Ontario. 


My most recent project, ‘Infinite Answers’ is an intricate look at the relationship between the pictorials of Art and Mathematics. Mathematics applies universally recognized symbols to create meaning which transcends all linguistic barriers. In Art, meaning similarly transcends linguistic barriers by the use of pictorials, but the resulting meaning has a subjectivity that is usually considered the polar opposite of Mathematics; except where Mathematics operates in its purest form. ‘Infinite Answers’ sets out to explore the relationship between the logical-pictorial language of Mathematics and the subjective-pictorial language of Fine Art through the creation of randomly generated and ultimately meaningless artistic ‘equations’.


These universally-recognized images have been manipulated graphically for the purpose of this installation so that they can be projected in random sequences and in large format, with the aid of five projectors. Each image forms one fifth of a nonsensical equation; images are generated randomly by each of the five projectors, creating an infinite number of possible equations. Unlike the opposing universal language of Mathematics, each artistic ‘equation’ invites a response in the viewer that is entirely subjective. The purpose is to question the relationship, and diametrical opposition, of the pictorial languages of Mathematics and Art. 


 

‘Infinite Answers’ is flexible in design and can function effectively in both an interior or exterior space. However an interior space would be ideal for it would allow the projections to be accompanied with the painting series, creating a higher visual stimulus and audience interaction. An interior space would also have a higher safety value given that the use of electronics is mandatory.


A date has been set for this show, Saturday September the 29th 2012. This coincides with Nuit Blanche, an all night Art Festival here in Toronto, Canada. My application has been submitted to the festival, and I will keep you posted if I am accepted. Regardless, the city streets will be crowded with art enthusiasts, so I will still have my show on this date. 


A location has been found, and negotiation is currently ongoing for use of the site for this coming September. The space also provides its own projectors and the facility and has ample room for both the paintings and the projections. The venue in question can also accommodate a large crowd, so there would be no concerns of line ups or over crowding.


What your help will do for this project

About 85% of the money being raised for this project will go towards the rental fee of a venue space, use of their equipment and staff for a full 24 hours. 

 

The remainder will go towards painting supplies and equipment needed to put on an amazing show.


Other Ways You Can Help


 

Remember folks, any help is greatly appreciated. Be sure to tell your friends, family, acquaintances, enemies, strangers, anyone. Pass on the word, and with all your help, lets make this project happen!

Use the share links to help spread the word!

Thank you!

story:
Our Story

Hello everyone! The video you just watched is from DUM DUM Zine's launch party in September. Since then we have made many new friends, including the wonderful people who are putting together FMLY Fest, Los Angeles' only solar powered D.I.Y. music and arts festival. 


At FMLY Fest this December 29 and 30, DUM DUM Zine is doing its second crowd-sourced disposable camera installation! We've launched this campaign in order to raise the money we need in order to buy, install and develop the disposable cameras.


  

  


We tethered four disposable cameras to DUM DUM signs FYFest this summer, and asked concert-goers to take snapshots of their experience. This time weâ€™re upgrading to TEN cameras (or more, depending on how much money we make!) spread out over the course of two days of the festival. 


  


At the end of this social experiment, we'll publish all the fantastic footage on the DUM DUM website for festival-goers and DUM DUM readers to click through and enjoy. Check out the original gallery HERE! 




The Impact

Photographers and fans often spend more time taking photos than actually enjoying festivals. Weâ€™ve learned that the most genuine way to have a good festival experience is to interact with itâ€”weâ€™ll handle the photo part so that you guys can have fun! At the end of the night weâ€™ll collect the cameras and publish the photos on our website. 


What We Need & What You Get

Unfortunately, nostalgia has its price. Film and development isnâ€™t cheapâ€”we need your help in order to buy, install, and develop the photos from our installation. 

We don't need much: even a simple $5 is almost enough to buy one disposable camera!

From the start, we've built DUM DUM together ourselves. The fine folks over at FMLY Fest are doing it all together and doing it all themselves. It's an honor to be a part of such a wonderful communal movement, and we would really like to make an artistic contribution as DUM DUM to all the FMLY fun. Help bring the community closer together!


All the funds earned from our IndieGoGo campaign will directly fund the purchase, installation and development of the disposable camera project. Any proceeds from the funds will go straight into DUM DUM's next camera project, 27 DUM DAYS: A Disposable Camera Tumblr, launching January 1, 2012.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word and "Share" this campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, and more! 


Come along to FMLY Fest and have some fun while supporting amazing artists!


Tell all your friends to join in on the fun, too!

story:
We are starting a fund raising campaign that offers great gifts with every donation that you make!


Please help us to reach our goal of $2500 by October 31, 2011.


What You Get for Your Contribution

We have partnered with several organizations to offer you a fantastic package for your contribution!


$5+

  • special mention in all of the Toronto Free generated media materials


___________________

$25+

  • A one year digital subscription to BlackFlash Magazine www.blackflash.ca
  • special mention in all of the Toronto Free generated media materials


___________________

$75+

  • One year print subscription to BlackFlash Magazine www.blackflash.ca
  • One year print subscription to FUSE Magazine. www.fusemagazine.org
  • One year print subscription to C Magazine. www.cmagazine.com
  • special mention in all of the Toronto Free generated media materials

___________________

$125+

  • The first two people to join at this level receive a festival pass to imagineNATIVE 2011. www.imaginenative.org
  • One year print subscription to BlackFlash Magazine www.blackflash.ca
  • One year print subscription to FUSE Magazine. www.fusemagazine.org
  • One year print subscription to C Magazine. www.cmagazine.com
  • Buy one dinner entree and receive the 2nd of equal or lesser value for 1/2 at The Bloordale Pantry. www.thebloordalepantry.com
  • Two complimentary tickets to the Bridge Dinner Series at Toronto Free Gallery
  • special mention in all of the Toronto Free generated media materials


Toronto Free Gallery is a not-for-profit art space dedicated to providing a forum for social, cultural and urban issues expressed through all media. Toronto Free Gallery is intended to be a creative laboratory. We aim to provide artists with a space to experiment, explore new ideas, question norms and challenge both themselves and their audiences.

TFG occupies a distinct role within the city's cultural ecology. We are the only gallery in Toronto whose programmes consistently highlight and offer creative responses to urgent social justice issues. We are also unique in Toronto by consistently fostering collaboration between creative communities through exhibitions and events that include people from diverse practices such as artists, activists, writers, architects, urban planners, ecologists, and front-line health care workers, to name a few.


What we need from you?

In order for you to receive your contribution gifts we will need for you to provide the following information:

name, address, telephone number, email. If you have additional questions please contact heather@torontofreegallery.org

Where does your contribution go?

The money that we receive goes to bringing you innovative programming on current social, cultural and urban issues by world renowned artists such as James Luna, Guillermo Gomez Pena, The Pinky Show and ATSA (Action Terroriste Socialement Acceptable). It also helps us support the work of emerging and established artists through exhibitions such as our new speaker series The Bridge, Creative Activism, Stripping Mining for Creative Cities, T-Dot Pioneers and Power to the People: The Work of Emory Douglass.


Toronto Free would like to give a special thanks to all the organizations who have contributed to this campaign: BlackFlash Magazine, Bloordale Pantry, C Magazine, imagineNATIVE and FUSE Magazine.

story:
Arts After School Project Overview
The Gayle Creative mission is to provide high quality arts and arts education for young people in urban communities.  Student success is our highest priority.  This campaign seeks to provide resources for a project for 80 elementary school students at Buffalo Public School #6.  The students will create visual art, music, and food art in an afterschool enrichment program.

The Need
The project needs art supplies and materials for student projects.  The needs include paper, paints, paintbrushes, food indgredients, t-shirts, and printing supplies.  Your donation will be used to purchase the materials for student projects.

Donate Today
Your tax-deductible donation to the Gayle Creative Institute will help us provide educational enrichment through the arts.

The Institute's programs are dependent on contributions from individuals like you.

Please support the transformative life experiences that the arts provide for young people. We make it easy for you to make a difference in a young person's life by offering many ways to donate.

Project Details
Who:  80 students in grades 3-8.  Gayle Creative Institute in partnership with Concerned Ecumenical Ministries and Ravelle Catering.

What:  After-school arts enrichment.

When:  January 7 - May 24, 2013.  Daily activities after school.  Two 10-week sessions.  Students will showcase their work in March and May.

Where:  Buffalo Public School #6.  Buffalo, NY.

Why:  To create unique, creative opportunities that motivate students to learn and succeed in school.  Research shows that "quality instruction in music, dance, theatre and visual art results in a wide array of social and academic benefits for students, including the ability to keep students in school and on track for graduation." (Center for Arts Education 2011).

How:  Engaging arts projects, including:

  • Studio Arts - Students create visual art using paint, collage, papier-mache, and video. 
  • Guitar Workshop - Students learn to play fun songs with melodies and chords on the guitar at a beginner level.
  • Screen Printing - Students create logos and other designs for t-shirt printing.
  • Fun Food Art - Students create edible artwork.  Cookie and cupcake decorating, fruit pizzas and other foods that are both beautiful and delicious.


About the Gayle Creative Institute and the Buffalo-Niagara Region
The Buffalo-Niagara region has a population of approximately 1.1 million persons. American Style Magazine has consistently ranked Buffalo among the top 25 mid-size city arts destinations, even putting Buffalo at number one in 2006 and 2008.  Buffalo boasts world-renowned arts institutions such as the Albright-Knox Art Gallery, Frank Lloyd Wright buildings, and the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra.

At the same time, a May 2011 Center for Arts Education (CFAE) policy brief shows that the Buffalo School District reports that 49 percent of schools have insufficient arts funding.  Most importantly, CFAE notes: "research shows that quality instruction in music, dance, theatre and visual art results in a wide array of social and academic benefits for students, including the ability to keep students in school and on track for graduation...Buffalo, with a graduation rate hovering around 57 percent, and one of the lowest graduation rates for black males across the country, would be remiss to disinvest in arts education as it seeks to reverse this trend."

Most schools in the Buffalo-Niagara region have reduced arts education.  Academic achievement, opportunities for students to learn discipline and collaborative skills, community enrichment are all  degraded by the loss of arts education.  There is, clearly, a compelling need for more arts education and programming in the Buffalo-Niagara region.

The Gayle Creative Institute seeks to address the need for arts education in Buffalo.  The institute offers arts (media, music, and visual art) education, performances, exhibitions, individual lessons, classes, and workshops.  The Institute's offerings not only fill an important gap in arts education but serve to develop positive community values.  Those values frame the philosophy of the institute:  Inspired arts education.

To achieve its mission the Gayle Creative Institute seeks to:

  • Provide high-quaility arts programming.
  • Collaborate with world-class artists to bring the finest creative education to the individuals and communities served by the institute.
  • Remain a positive force in the communities served the institute by advancing the values of love, respect, discipline, and integrity.

The Gayle Creative Institute serves schools and communities with access to the arts. The project creates opportunities for students and community members to engage in arts programming through performances and arts education. In collaboration with arts professionals, the institute produces performances, conducts workshops and seminars, and sponsors access to high-quality cultural institutions and events.

story:
Our Story

My name is Alon Atlanta. I, together with more than 100 artists from all over the southeast, are creating "Burn to Peace."  Already, we have begun to have big pARTies in the Atlanta area.  Through art and creativity, we are building a community. The money donated will go to the idea of bringing people throughout the world together through this principle.

The Impact

The idea is to show as many people as possible how a positive community can bring people together.  One of our ways of connection is through art and the Burning Man lifestyle, which focuses on the 10 Burning Man principles.  We believe through this way of life, we can find happiness while being surrounded by art.

The 10 Burning Man Principles are:

"Radical Inclusion
Anyone may be a part of Burning Man. We welcome and respect the stranger. No prerequisites exist for participation in our community.

Gifting
Burning Man is devoted to acts of gift giving. The value of a gift is unconditional. Gifting does not contemplate a return or an exchange for something of equal value.

Decommodification
In order to preserve the spirit of gifting, our community seeks to create social environments that are unmediated by commercial sponsorships, transactions, or advertising. We stand ready to protect our culture from such exploitation. We resist the substitution of consumption for participatory experience.

Radical Self-reliance
Burning Man encourages the individual to discover, exercise and rely on his or her inner resources.

Radical Self-expression
Radical self-expression arises from the unique gifts of the individual. No one other than the individual or a collaborating group can determine its content. It is offered as a gift to others. In this spirit, the giver should respect the rights and liberties of the recipient.

Communal Effort
Our community values creative cooperation and collaboration. We strive to produce, promote and protect social networks, public spaces, works of art, and methods of communication that support such interaction.

Civic Responsibility
We value civil society. Community members who organize events should assume responsibility for public welfare and endeavor to communicate civic responsibilities to participants. They must also assume responsibility for conducting events in accordance with local, state and federal laws.

Leaving No Trace
Our community respects the environment. We are committed to leaving no physical trace of our activities wherever we gather. We clean up after ourselves and endeavor, whenever possible, to leave such places in a better state than when we found them.

Participation
Our community is committed to a radically participatory ethic. We believe that transformative change, whether in the individual or in society, can occur only through the medium of deeply personal participation. We achieve being through doing. Everyone is invited to work. Everyone is invited to play. We make the world real through actions that open the heart.

Immediacy
Immediate experience is, in many ways, the most important touchstone of value in our culture. We seek to overcome barriers that stand between us and a recognition of our inner selves, the reality of those around us, participation in society, and contact with a natural world exceeding human powers. No idea can substitute for this experience."

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal its to have the best pARTy in the world.  What is a pARTy?  pARTy is a celebration that focuses on all forms and mediums of art from visual to performance to music to healing.  It is a once in lifetime experience that blends each unique artform into one night of fun.

 

We need $100,000 to create our first burn which will be October 2012 in Israel.  The middle east is a prime example of a place that needs to be brought together and we feel that we can be an insturment in bringing people together.


Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways you can help.  The first way is just to stay posted, we are doing a lot of things all the time.  Come and join us!  The second way is to donate your time, money, art, performance, volunteer work or any form of self expression and love that you have to offer.  The third is to ENJOY!

story:
Fully Functional!

The Fully Functional Cabaret is about to be born! Two years in the making, one year in full-tilt production, this project is more than song, dance, and inflatable genitalia.

FFC is a theatrical performance by a group of six trans women, three from San Francisco, Two from New York, and one from Los Angeles. We are, at the core of our efforts, working to produce an honest and heartfelt love letter to trans womanhood.

Beyond that, we hope to reach out to our wider communities to say: "No More Sob Stories!" Our tales will be told with incandescent aplomb by our deepest selves. The hard parts will never be overcome if we don't reach past victimhood with brighter expectations.

One quite common experience of trans womanhood is isolation. This is our go at peeling back that veil.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $2500 more dollars to make this show fly high. Key to the ethics at this show's heart is respecting the stories of the people involved, and in a world where trans women are seriously economically disadvantaged, that can mean paying them. To complete our budget, we will need $250 per performer more than we currently have.

In addition to artist stipends, the remaining $1000 will go toward our glamorous sets and costumes and help complete our technical budget (we need $300 more for a brilliant techie to meet our light and sound needs).

We have received funding from the Queer Cultural Center and the San Francisco Arts Commission, and the last push will be this remaining $2500 of our budget.

And remember: every dollar over $2000 goes straight to the performers!

...No, Really, What You Get:

  • A donation of $20 gets you a signed photo of the cast!
  • A donation of $35 garners the above and a handcrafted, artisan thank you note!
  • A donation of $75 comes with the above and a CD by Shawna Virago!
  • A donation of $100 is reflected in the above and a Fully Functional Cabaret t-shirt!
  • A donation of $250 will help you acquire all of the above and a stimulating, conversational tea time with Annie Danger (Skype/gChat if necessary)
  • A donation of $500 or more will personally acquaint you with all of the many above thank you gifts AND a phone message personally spoken/sung by the entire cast (mp3 available if necessary)

The Impact

Supporting The Fully Functional Cabaret supports the radical expansion of what trans allyship, trans community, and queer art can look like. We are looking to feed a number of birds with this bush, not the least of which inlcude: creating more brilliant trans culture, putting the 'T' more firmly back into 'LGBT', challenging meanings of allyhood and spectatorship, healing through group performance, experimenting with utopic performatives, paying trans women (!), and planting a seed that can flourish into a nationally-touring show.

Annie Danger, the facilitator of this project, has a long and committed history to transformative (no pun intended...much) performance that doesn't lose a single ounce of fun and humor for all its earnesty. She has brought the world multiple full-length shows, including It's That Easy! With Terry VanWeen!, a motivational seminar for the revolution, and The Great Church of the Holy Fuck, a queer spiritual service about the power and healing in deeply queer sex and bodylove.

Other Ways You Can Help

Ooh! I don't have a ton of money either. If you don't have $5, $10, or $1000 for this campaign, no problem! Please:
  • Pass the word on! Tell your friends! Spread this campaign ALL OVER Facebutt, Twitter, and the rest of the internets!
  • If you're in the Bay Area this July, just come and see it!
  • If you're in the Bay Area this June, help us build sets and flyer!
  • Love trans women!

story:
Introduction

Hi there. My name is Heather Johnson; I’ve been a practicing visual artist for close to 20 years. Late last year I was offered a month-long Artist Residency fellowship at BoxoHOUSE, a residency program in Joshua Tree, California dedicated to the investigation and development of ideas related to place, community and the environment.  

This is a dream come true for me - part of something I've fantasized of ever since I made the unlikely discovery 6 years ago that despite my small size, I am capable of riding motorcycles. I took it as a sign, and gave notice at my job.

This spring, I will ride my motorcycle from my home in northern New Jersey to Joshua Tree, beyond and back, alone. I will make a new collection of art works based on my experiences in Joshua Tree, the Mojave Desert and what I see during this journey...and I will leave a trail of art works at sites around the country, that anyone can encounter, take and keep.

To do this, I need your help.

Me, my work and the frightening and beautiful

Riding a motorcycle feels like flying. Other than a helmet and protective leathers, there are no barriers to isolate you from the wind, passing trees or the road itself.  There is no cinematic lens through which to view the passing landscape - you are a part of the landscape itself.

My work is about the relationship between the land, the sky and my own body. I am fascinated with the movement inside an engine as it relates to circulations within the body itself. The repeating, propelling explosions of a combustion engine express a profound statement about creativity – the necessity of destruction in the act of creation.  I make embroideries, using stitches fine enough to give the appearance of pen-and-ink line drawings from a distance.  This repetitive labor is sweetly cyclical, a slow meditation upon the rapid-fire action of the pistons that feed its inspiration.  Layers of information overlap and are woven together to bring about new relationships and meanings as I try to make sense of this enormous universe within which we are spinning continuously.  You can learn more about my work and background via my website at http://www.heatherLjohnson.com.

For In Search of the Frightening and Beautiful I will ride across the country looking for dramatic marks in the landscape made by humans in the name of art, science or "progress".  Strip mines, toxic waste dumps, and the monumental earthworks of Robert Smithson and others all qualify as targets for this exploration.  From each site I will take something: a photo, pamphlet, piece of trash, or anything else that reveals the essence of that place. Using these materials, I will make a new collection of embroideries at BoxoHOUSE -- small studies that will eventually lead to larger-scale works.

At any place from which I take, I will leave a piece of myself: a calling card in the form of a hand-embroidered rendering of my body and the machine that carried me there.  Pieces of my body, and pieces of my bike: hands, feet, ears, breasts, pistons, alternators, gears, nuts and bolts. Like a trail of breadcrumbs, there will be bits of me left all around the country for people to encounter and wonder about later.  There will be a blog with road stories, photos and my route map, in case anyone out there wants to trace my steps and hunt down my breadcrumbs…check it out now at http://thefrighteningandbeautiful.blogspot.com/. 

Why do I need money, and where is it going?

Well, it's quite simple. A 10,000 mile road trip is an expensive proposition, no matter how frugal you are.  I will camp, stay with friends and eat from food stands, grocery stores and cheap diners whenever possible. Though my bike sips gas, fuel alone will run around $1000 for the trip and my month-long stay in Joshua Tree.  

My $11,500 goal will cover not only food, accommodations and gas, but motorcycle maintenance, art project-related expenses, and my share of the rent that still must be paid while I'm gone.  There is also some allotted for the unforeseen, such as towing, incident-related bike repairs and 2 months of health insurance that I really hope I don't need.

Even the smallest donation will help tremendously!

$10 will pay for a tank of gas or lunch somewhere on the road.  $25 will get me a campsite and a bundle of wood for a campfire.  $50 will buy me a room on the inevitable night I get caught in a crazy thunderstorm.  If you wanna get really generous, $500 will pay for the 6000-mile service my bike will need once I get to Joshua Tree!

What'll you get in return?

Aside from my deep and permanent gratitude, I've created a few perks I hope you will enjoy.  For a donation of $25, you will get an acknowledgement in my blog and on Facebook, as well as a signed photograph taken on the trip and email updates sent from the road; for $25 more I'll also send you a hand-written postcard from one of the cities or towns I pass through.

For those willing to shell out $125 or more, you'll get everything mentioned plus a signed book packed with images and anecdotes that'll make a great keepsake.   For $250 I will stitch your name by hand to a linen swatch and let it fly out into the landscape forever in your honor... you will of course get a photograph of this.  And if you are one of those rare souls in the position to donate really big sums, there are original works of art in it for you! 

Your assistance will help raise the visibility of women motorcyclists in the U.S. and will blur boundaries between the two very distinct worlds of art practice and motorcycle culture.  But most importantly, you will be supporting a dream that, to me, signifies the heart and soul of what most work so hard for – freedom -- to roam, to create, to squeeze every drop of meaning out of life.

Other ways to help

We are all still struggling like hell in this unfortunate economy.  Many of you east-coasters affected by Hurricane Sandy are still coping with the damage it wrought, and will be hurting from that for a long time to come.  Others face challenges I can't begin to fathom that make this campaign seem trivial.  

If helping financially is not an option, I hope you'll help me spread the word!  

If you like the concept of this project, follow my blog and post a comment or hit the Facebook "share" button, as you can bet there will be moments where I'll need the moral support - those west Texas roads are going to get lonely!  If I pass through your neck of the woods and you know of a cheap place to crash or a good place to eat, I'd love to hear about it - post it on the project Facebook page and let me know!

Your support in whatever form it takes means more to me than I can express. THANK YOU!

Heather

Well, it's quite simple. A 10,000 mile road trip is an expensive proposition, no matter how frugal you are.  I will camp, stay with friends and eat from food stands, grocery stores and cheap diners whenever possible. Though my bike sips gas, fuel alone will run around $1000 for the trip and my month-long stay in Joshua Tree.  
My $11,500 goal will cover not only food, accommodations and gas, but motorcycle maintenance, art project-related expenses, and my share of the rent that still must be paid while I'm gone.  There is also some allotted for the unforeseen, such as towing, incident-related bike repairs and 2 months of health insurance that I really hope I don't need.
Even the smallest donation will help tremendously!
$10 will pay for a tank of gas or lunch somewhere on the road.  $25 will get me a campsite and a bundle of wood for a campfire.  $50 will buy me a room on the inevitable night I get caught in a crazy thunderstorm.  If you wanna get really generous, $500 will pay for the 6000-mile service my bike will need once I get to Joshua Tree!
What'll you get in return?
Aside from my deep and permanent gratitude, I've created a few perks I hope you will enjoy.  For a donation of $25, you will get an acknowledgement in my blog and on Facebook, as well as a signed photograph taken on the trip and email updates sent from the road; for $25 more I'll also send you a hand-written postcard from one of the cities or towns I pass through.
For those willing to shell out $125 or more, you'll get everything mentioned plus a signed book packed with images and anecdotes that'll make a great keepsake.   For $250 I will stitch your name by hand to a linen swatch and let it fly out into the landscape forever in your honor... you will of course get a photograph of this.  And if you are one of those rare souls in the position to donate really big sums, there are original works of art in it for you! 
Your assistance will help raise the visibility of women motorcyclists in the U.S. and will blur boundaries between the two very distinct worlds of art practice and motorcycle culture.  But most importantly, you will be supporting a dream that, to me, signifies the heart and soul of what most work so hard for – freedom -- to roam, to create, to squeeze every drop of meaning out of life.
Other ways to help


We are all still struggling like hell in this unfortunate economy.  Many of you east-coasters affected by Hurricane Sandy are still coping with the damage it wrought, and will be hurting from that for a long time to come.  Others face challenges I can't begin to fathom that make this campaign seem trivial.  
If helping financially is not an option, I hope you'll help me spread the word!  
If you like the concept of this project, follow my blog and post a comment or hit the Facebook "share" button, as you can bet there will be moments where I'll need the moral support - those west Texas roads are going to get lonely!  If I pass through your neck of the woods and you know of a cheap place to crash or a good place to eat, I'd love to hear about it - post it on the project Facebook page and let me know!
Your support in whatever form it takes means more to me than I can express. THANK YOU!
Heather

story:
Our Goal: Rehabilitate former child soldiers through painting

Thousands of young boys were kidnapped, given drugs, and made to fight in a 14-year civil war. They were forced to commit the worst atrocities and war crimes known to man. After the war, they were abandoned and rejected. Their generals disappeared, their families rejected them, and society has driven them out. Now, they are homeless and without skills to create a normal life.

It is our goal, our mission, to save these young men. With your help, they can be rescued from the streets, and rehabilitated, through art.  

Painting unlocks their creative intelligence and is the best way for us to better understand what they've experienced. Imagine what their art could reveal about life and the strength of the human spirit! Painting will bring peace and hope to former child soldiers and the money raised will enable more boys to begin healing through art. 

After all the rejection they've faced, this is our opportunity to accept them and support them in creating something that is truly valuable. This may be their only opportunity to express themselves appropriately and begin mending the emotional and psychological damage that has been done.

Please back our project so we can support these boys and share their message through art with the world.  

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $25,000 so we can help more boys abandon their addictions, learn life skills, and heal from their experiences though art. When boys are rescued from the streets, they come to us bruised, scarred, abandoned, neglected, and suffering from addictions. After six months of rehabilitation, they are drug free and have learned to work together. The program gives them the skills necessary to create a normal life for themselves, their families, and the country of Liberia. 

The money raised will go directly to providing the former child soldiers clothing, food, shelter, and rehabilitation. These boys are taught to work together, solve problems, speak French, drive automobiles, and heal from the horror they have experienced. The art they create in this program will help them heal, and will also give them a positive creative outlet. 

By supporting our cause, you create peace, peace for former child soldiers, women, children, and the country of Liberia. By rescuing the boys from the street, you are creating safety for women and children, and helping the entire country heal. 

Backers of our cause have the opportunity to receive some amazing rewards. Some of the rewards include: pictures and stories of the boys, watercolor prints and original art created by the child soldiers, hand-beaded wooden bracelets, hand-carved wooden tribal masks, or even a trip with Sahbu.org to help build schools, collect the art, and rescue more boys. 

The Impact

There are over 40,000 former child soldiers in Liberia. With your help, these boys will become responsible fathers, leaders, teachers, and business owners. Right now, thousands of boys are still homeless, living in cemetaries and abandoned buildings, without education or the even the skills necessary to have a normal life. By contributing, you help boys become men - honest, educated men, that want to help their country heal and progress.

Each day these boys are painting in hopes that one day they can sell their artwork to the world, and use the funds to save their brothers. You can make this dream come true for them, and help rescue more former child soldiers. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribue financially, you can still make a huge difference for these boys. 

Please talk about the child soldiers. Talk about our campaign. 

Use the share tools to tell your friends about what we are doing. If everyone shares this story, thousands of lives will be saved. And beautiful art work will be displayed all over the world. Help these boys heal, and create beauty.

story:
My Story

Portable Ensemble is a project for a residency at Proyecto ’ACE in Beunos Aires during June 2012. For the initial proposal, I wanted to engage the public with a set of portable chairs that could be arranged in a variety of locations. The chairs would be transported using a bicycle and a wagon.

To extend the project beyond its initial context, I am interested in making prints using the slats of the chairs. Each person who donates $60 or more to the project will have his or her name carved into one of the seat slats. In exchange, that person will receive a limited edition woodblock print.

The Impact

Through this project, I want to look at the viability of making art during a time of widespread economic recessions and disparities. By allowing people to receive a work via donation, I want to have a more direct connection with my audience. The base donation of $60 roughly covers the cost of making and sending someone a print. So, in order to make the project vital, I need people to sponsor it, not only due to the costs, but so that I have a subject to work with.

What I Need & What You Get

The approximate cost of making an edition of three prints is as follows: 

  • $5 for paper
  • $1 for ink
  • $5 for a mailing tube
  • $35 for postage to mail the print

 

The cost of using IndieGoGo is 4% of the donations if I meet my goal, and 9% if I don't. PayPal charges 3% for transaction fees, so I'm adding 12% to the initial cost of making each print, or roughly $50.

 

I have to make sure to cover the cost of each print, as the cost of the residency is already high, and I am not eligible for federal and provincial grants in Canada as a full-time student. So, if there is money left over from each print, it will help cover the cost of the residency. But, I want to avoid using this as a platform to fund my trip, and keep the project focused on the value and viability of making art.

Although I come from a background in sculpture, I am excited to have the opportunity to make prints. Carving a woodblock for a print has much of the same appeal as carving wood for a three-dimensional object, but with a two-dimensional result.


Other Ways You Can Help

The Internet is unsurpassed at quickly generating support for an idea. If you are interested in my project, even if you can't support it, please let others know about it.

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Keys and I have been helping my grandmother for the past 6 months and since she needs 24/7 surveillance I can't leave her alone I spend 97% of my time in the house with her. I have a few years experience working in film in many departments from makeup, to set-dressing
  • I'm completely self taught. 
  • I started doing makeup a few years back when I was inspired by the NYC nightlife, although makeup/ body paints are expensive and my collection is still small even though I spend every spare cent on it.
  • Therefore with this project I hope to enhance my life as well as anyone who might view my artwork (including the models I paint)... and Bring the extreme art of body painting to NYC
  • My Dream is to become a recognized Body Painter, and since I have never been fortunate with money, this project will help me create what I couldn't otherwise.
  • But with these funds I plan to create at least 10 full body designs

What I Need & What You Get

  • I need about 11k on the short end so I can fully create all realms of body art, the money will be spent on lighting, camera, and of course lots and lots of makeup and body paints including paint/makeup brushes as well as an airbrush. Also any additional things I may need to keep my models completely comfortable while being painted such as robes. 
  • my perks I hope to involve everyone that helps me a possible chance to inspire a project as well as share the experience.
  • If I don't reach my goal, I plan to save the money and try again to raise the money to start this project
  • ALL DONORS WILL ALSO BE INVITED TO A LIVE SHOW to watch me from start to finish on one project

The Impact

  • This project is valuable, especially to me, cause I wanna show how inspiring art can really be.
  • Once my goal is reached you can check out my youtube to see updates as they come, and are also invited to countless live streams

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't help out I understand, just spread the word to others that you think might find this project interesting
  • Also, don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Also, try to make this viral (if you can :D), as advertising is difficult for me since I spend every moment of my day making sure my grandmother is safe/ comfortable.

I'm currently unable to promote as much as I would like as I am taking care of my sick grandmother 24/7 (don't sleep much). So your help would be magical :)

*once I get funding I can find someone to help w/ my grandmother on the days I create the body art

story:
Hi My Friends!!!

I am so excited and grateful to all of you for being here in this thrilling moment as I begin to launch my Career as a Solo Artist. 

For the past 3 years I've been Singing with the Guruganesha Band-

Check out this beautiful video : Thousand Suns

And now in order to honor my multi-cultural path as a musician/artist, I am gathering all my courage and reinvesting every dollar I have earned to launch the next phase of my Career. 

I just finished my first SOLO CD and if you contribute you will be one of the FIRST people to receive the ALBUM!

My dream is about sharing my music with a global community and contributing to heal the world. As an Artist/Musician, I've devoted most of my life to walking the path of Spirit and now I am taking my practice of Sonic Healing and Expression to the Next Level and it will rely on YOUR HELP!

I'm making huge investments  to produce a high end Music Video that merges the spiritual and earthly love in an Exhaulted Manifestation of Beauty. Expressing the Sensual Nature of the Human Experience and Longing for a higher love.

The promotion of this video and the promotion of my Upcoming SOLO CD plus the costs of putting together a Band and Tour are in need of support as well. 

THESE FUNDS WILL honor and will pay

1) First and foremost all the professionals that are already working full time to make my dream a reality. And this dream is about sharing my music with all of you and contributing to heal the world. 

2) These funds will contribute to pay the team of Viejo Lobo Films that with such professionalism are producing my Music Video in Tulum, Mexico. Now we are entering the third phase of the project that is post-production. I'm excited because with your support my very First Music Video will be completed and soon I will be able to share it with all of you. 

3) These funds will support the Promotion of my music video and will help to finance Paloma Devi 2014 tour, musicians, traveling and promotion. 

4) These funds also will help to pay for the development and maintenance of my website and all the other social media tools necessary for promotion and presence.  

5) Last but not least, these funds will help to reimburse me and keep me going after a huge financial investment I already made. As an independent artist I do not have a salary and now I am gathering all my courage and reinvesting every dollar I have earned to launch my SOLO CAREER. 

ANYTHING you contribute is WELCOMED and HIGHLY VALUED!

If you can't contribute financially you still can help by sharing this campaign with friends on FB, twitter or email.

Share with A friend... on your Page/Social Media... any amount of Dollars... a Prayer. 

Special Thanks

Very special thanks to Chía Ortegón who with her multi-talents and expertise has been by my side wearing many hats supporting me in every step.

Guruganesha Singh for all the Music we make, also for his Vision & Artistry in putting together such a wonderful group of musicians to collaborate with.

Charo Ruiz Ibiza, Paloma and Alberto for the amazing wardrobe for the video!

Alberto for the Support of the Sacred Masculine in the Video!

Yolanda Aguado for her service in Hair/Makeup and Spirit.

In deep gratitude with Lu Montiel the Light Keeper of Retiro Maya in Tulum, Mexico for her warm hospitality.

Thanks to all the community in Tulum, México that showed up to support the Production of my Music Video. 

And thanks to all of you for your contribution and support. I will take you all in my hearts as I move through this next phase of growth during the launching of my SOLO CAREER, these are exciting times. 

I deeply Love and Honor you ALL!

story:
Why am I doing this?

As a part of earning the rank of Eagle Scout, a Boy Scout must organize and complete an original public service project. For several months I struggled to generate ideas. I considered installing benches, building shade structures, landscaping, etc., but I couldn't develop a single idea that I was truly passionate about...that is until now.

As a high school senior, I have been touring colleges nonstop for the past year or so, and I noticed that everyone rides a bike. The faculty have noticed that too. They have also noticed that bicycles break and that most people don't carry tools when they go for a ride. As a result, some universities have installed outdoor bicycle repair stations, providing otherwise helpless students with a handful of essential tools and a pump. 

As a recreational cyclist, I have also noticed that the American River Parkway is an awesome place to ride. I eventually came to the conclusion that my project should in some way contribute to this wonderful trail that I too often take for granted. My intention is to install three public bicycle repair stations in high traffic areas along the American River Parkway.

What is a public bicycle repair station?

As you might find in a bike shop, this is a stand on which you can place your bicycle in order to perform maintenance and make simple repairs. The only difference is that this stand is meant for public use.

The specific model stand I intend to install is called the Dero Fixit. Its design is simpler than many competitors and, as a result, it appears more durable. The stand itself consists of a vertical steel tube bolted to a concrete pad and two smaller tubes parallel to the ground mounted on top. A cyclist can hang his/her bike from the parallel tubes either by the saddle or the top tube. Several crescent wrenches, tire levers, screwdrivers, and allen keys hang from steel cables inside of the tube and are easily accessible to the user. A durable bicycle pump, compatible with both Presta and Schrader valves, is attached to the side of the stand.

What can you do to help?

As you might expect, these repair stations are not cheap. Each stand costs $940 at minimum, not including shipping, and I also need to pour concrete pads. I originally considered manufacturing the stands on my own, but I concluded that a prefabricated product was superior in terms of durability and product support.

At minimum I aim to raise $2000. This will allow me to install two repair stations with basic air pumps. 

For each additional $285, I can upgrade one of the pumps to a superior model, reducing maintenance costs and increasing the lifespan of the repair station.

Even if you are unable to contribute, you can help me by spreading the word. Tell your family, friends, and fellow users of the American River Parkway. The more people we can get to donate, the more this project will benefit everyone on the bike trail.

Details

  • I plan to install the stands in three high-traffic areas: the Guy West Bridge, William B. Pond, and Sunrise. I will need to pour concrete pads at the Guy West Bridge and William B. Pond. 
  • The stands will be installed in highly visible areas, reducing the risk of vandalism.

Any donation is greatly appreciated. Thank you!

story:
Greetings!

My name is Jeanetmarie, and I’m the illustrator of Good Hair Cards. I was inspired to create the Good Hair Cards collection by the many fashionable greeting cards I saw in stores. Since I used to design business cards for hairstylists, I thought the beauty and diversity of Black hairstyles was perfect for a new greeting card line.

Good Hair Cards made its debut at the 2013 Black Women’s Expo in Chicago. I now have an opportunity to expand the line with 20 new Birthday cards and place them into stores through sales reps. So, I've launched this campaign to meet the cost of production because printing 20,000 cards is expensive!

Here's how the campaign works

Because I've put every penny I could afford into Good Hair Cards, your contribution will make it possible for me to print the new cards. As a thank you, I have created several perks. For $20, you will receive two greeting cards of your choice, one Sista Magnet and 100 bookmarks with space on the back for you to customize it with the name of your meeting, event or organization. 


They will listen if Ya holler

You have a powerful voice and your support will demonstrate to retailers like Duane Reade and Papyrus that this is a product you want to see in their stores. Just like a woman I once overheard in Duane Reade say to a friend, “I don’t like any of these cards for my sister.” I quickly pulled out three Good Hair Cards and offered to give the woman one for free, but she insisted on buying all three. Woo Hoo!

Join Team Good Hair Cards

With your pledges of support, I will have the funds needed to go towards printing the cards, buying bar codes and matching envelopes, and purchasing cello shelves to protect to the cards. I need a minimum of $5,000, but the more money that's pledged, the more card designs I can print. If I exceed my funding goal, I can pay my sale reps and promoter!   

The breakdown of costs: Indiegogo fees: 4%, Paypal fees: 3%, Taxes: 15%,  Perks: 10% and Production: 65%

Your pledge can take these girls from here…

..to here where you can buy them

Your pledge can make this happen...

...and when you walked into a store that carries Good Hair Cards, you can smile because your pledge put them there. Can't pledge? No worries. Anyone can spread the word and share this project on Facebook, Instagram, Tumblr or on a website as well as by using the hashtag #PutGoodhaircardsinstores

FrAQ

Some of the illustrations feature hair weaves. Is that good hair?

Yes! Good Hair Cards celebrates the freedom every woman has to define her own style.

What does it say on the back of the bookmark?

Click HERE to read message on back of bookmark.

You wrote a children's book?

Yes. I've written several children's books, and for this campaign, I am offering a digital copy of Grandma Jones and Murphy's Law. Click HERE to read the first two chapters.

Do I get to choose which cards and magnets I want?

Yes, and all the cards and magnets will be displayed on goodhaicards.com after the campaign is completed.

What is Digital Wallpaper?

I've created digital wallpaper for your cell phone featuring three different hair models, Afro, Weave and Locs with the quote “Dreams don’t expire.”

What is the Limited Edition Thank You Cards?

Just for this campaign, I’m designing a box set of 16 Thank You Cards featuring a hair model with either Natural or a Weave hairstyle.

What happens to my money if you don’t reach your goal?

I believe this campaign will be a success and reach its goal. In the unlikely event it does not, I will either print fewer cards depending on what is raised or refund the money if I can’t fulfill the perks.

Is my donation tax deductible?

Your donation is not tax deductible. Please note this is not a charitable donation, but a contribution to help print and produce Good Hair Cards. Therefore in exchange for your donation, you received a perk.

Thank you!

Thanks for considering this project. If there are any questions I haven't answered yet, please send me a message at info@goodhaircards.com. Cheers!
